		<date>2006-01-03</date>
		<username>Roland E. Zwick (magneteach@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The Art of Incoherence</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How can a movie be THIS compelling and engrossing, yet still be so difficult to follow? That is the question I found myself asking all the way through "Syriana," a fascinating political thriller that keeps you riveted to your seat for well over two hours yet is almost completely incomprehensible for most of that running time. The mark of a great filmmaker usually lies in how well he is able to illuminate a complex subject for a less-than-enlightened or essentially uninformed audience. In this case, however, writer/director Stephen Gaghan's refusal - or is it inability? - to unravel the entanglements in his narrative somehow works in the movie's favor. Is it because the subject matter itself is so messy and incoherent that the presentation of it needs to be as well? Whatever the case, "Syriana" is a wholly riveting and absorbing cinematic experience - even if only a tiny percentage of it makes any real sense. (And don't forget that coherence of plot, in and of itself, is not necessarily a prerequisite for a quality film. After all, it's widely admitted that the screenplay for "The Big Sleep" is virtually impossible to figure out, yet that film is considered a classic).Based on the book by Robert Baer, Gaghan's tale takes us to the dark heart of international oil politics, where strategies are planned and deals are struck, often at the expense of individual freedoms and the snuffing out of thousands of innocent lives. Gaghan shows us the behind-the-scenes wheeling and dealing, power politics, corporate corruption, governmental malfeasance, human exploitation and personal betrayals that go into filling up the gas tanks of our SUVs. In this turbulent Middle Eastern world of sectarian strife, arms deals and acts of terror, Gaghan finds little room for good guys or heroes, although he does imply that heroic ACTS may indeed be possible. Instead, he shows how all of us, to some degree or another, share in this shame.Rather than taking a purely linear approach in his narrative (which would certainly have made things more understandable) , Gaghan, as he did in "Traffic," provides us with an assortment of characters and story lines that often seem arbitrary and disconnected from one another. This is primarily why the confusion arises, for we are often whisked from one subplot to another before the first has been fully explicated. The film is something like a mosaic; it doesn't really matter if every single detail doesn't attain complete clarity as long as we are able to pull back and focus our eyes on the big picture Gaghan shows us.There's not much point in trying to relate the fine points of the complex plot here. Suffice it to say that the film is filled with vivid scenes and memorable moments, as well as outstanding performances by George Clooney, Matt Damon, Christopher Plummer, Chris Cooper, Amanda Peet, Kayvan Novak, Amr Waked and many others.By plunging headlong into the most timely and important issue of our time - the violent clash between Western secularism and Muslim extremism - "Syriana" certainly establishes itself as one of the bravest and best movies of 2005. However, it may take a few additional viewings on the part of the head-scratchers to convince THEM of that.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-12-12</date>
		<username>Ed Uyeshima</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Oil Companies Under Fire in Politically Charged But Overly Convoluted Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you have read Kenneth Pollack's penetrating book about the current political malaise in Iran, "The Persian Puzzle: The Conflict Between Iran and America", you will have some idea of what writer-director Stephen Gaghan is attempting to portray in this tightly paced, atmospheric but ultimately confusing thriller. The movie's social commitment is impressive, but the narrative is so fragmented and some actions so vaguely motivated that the result is unfortunately something of a muddle for much of its 126-minute running time. By traipsing the globe in brief scenes one after the other, Gaghan attempts to peel the layers off the complex and often corrupt relationships among American oil companies, intelligence agencies, the government and the ruling class of the oil-rich Persian Gulf. With its shaky hand-held camera-work and lightning-quick pacing, the movie bears a striking similarity to Stephen Soderbergh's version of "Traffic" (he is an executive producer here) but not in terms of its dramatic resonance.There are at least four separate stories that intertwine through the various locales, most intriguingly in a fictional Arab country where one of two sons is about to become the ruling emir. Which one is selected has direct bearing on a high-profile merger between two oil companies in Texas. There is another subplot focused on a Pakistani oil worker whose frustrations with the oil companies lead him toward drastic measures. None of these strands are very clear at the outset, nor how they are interrelated. I kept hoping there would be a more lucid portrayal of the volatile Middle East situation amid the military forces and oil companies. Instead, like what Fernando Meirelles does with "The Constant Gardener", which has a similar disregard for the major pharmaceutical companies in Africa, Gaghan seems to be going for a more visceral tone to drive his story, and on that level, it works.What also works is the stellar acting even if the characters are so elliptical in motivation that you need a playbook to keep up with their stories. The three leads are quite effective. As Bob Barnes, a rogue CIA operative respected for his experience but alienated by his entrepreneurial approach to his work, George Clooney appears to be evolving nicely into character roles that stretch his skills. Through soulful gazes and some brutalizing scenes of torture, he is able to convey his character's conscience with a minimum of fuss. Matt Damon is ideally cast as Bryan Woodman, a derivatives trader and global finance expert who provides guidance to the "good" son, a progressive Arab prince who really wants to restructure his country's economy for lasting benefit to its citizenry. Jeffrey Wright continues to impress as Bennett Holiday, an ambitious Washington lawyer ordered by his boss to not only vet the oil merger but rubber stamp it. Intriguingly, all three characters have been given more personal profiles - Barnes has a college-age son with whom he feels estranged, Woodman goes through the loss of a child, and Holiday has a resentful alcoholic father - but none of these dimensions are explored with any depth.Gaghan has certainly assembled an extensive cast, and there are solid contributions from Alexander Siddig as the reform-minded Prince Nasir Al-Subaai, Chris Cooper as one of the oil company CEOs, Christopher Plummer as Holiday's corrupt boss, Jayne Atkinson as the poker-faced CIA division chief, and Amanda Peet as Woodman's inconsolable wife. In even smaller roles are stalwarts such as William Hurt, David Clennon and an emphatic Tim Blake Nelson. Despite the film's intentions and often powerful execution, I just wish the film was far less convoluted and the storyline more streamlined within its framework. By the way, one of many unexplained details is the title, Syriana, which is a Washington insider term referring to the notion that the US can recast developing nations in our own image.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>phony premise</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of the film's central themes involves the emerging nature of a relationship between big oil in the US and in the Mid-East. In fact, there is nothing emergent about this relationship; it is as mature as a 50 year old French Bordeaux. The Bush family and other powerful families in the US oil industry have enjoyed cozy relationships with the Saudis and others like them for decades. So for me the sense of reality most people talk about regarding this film is completely phony, reducing the film to an elaborate cartoon. The film-maker would have been better served if he had told a traditional three-act story within the context of the cross-cultural elitism that typifies relations between the aristocracies in the US and other oil rich nations. The truth is that such people completely ignore 99 percent of the world population's needs in order to line their own pockets. A story told whereby the director endeavored to make the audience feel thusly ignored would have been much more unsettling and effective.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>At first confusing but eventually powerful political thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I watched Syriana for the first time I was confused and infuriated. During the first half nothing seemed to happen, the plot was garbled and the motives of the characters were left unclear. I needed to watch it 3 times more to fully absorb all the twists and nuances of the story, and even now it feels the movie hasn't revealed everything about itself. It's one of the most complex and challenging movies I've seen, but also one of the most rewarding.Syriana is a movie very similar to Steven Soderberg's Traffic, using multiple story lines and characters surrounding one big subject (this is not a surprise, Syriana's director Stephen Gaghan also wrote Traffic). In Traffic it was drugs and its illegal trade, in Syriana it's Mideastern oil and the competition for it. An unnamed Arab state declines the offer of Connex, an American oil giant, and makes a sale with the Chinese. To avoid defeat, Connex merges with a smaller oil company called Killen, that has managed to make contract of the oil in Kazakstan. U.S. Justice department scents something shadowy in the project, doubting that there's corruption behind Killen's deal with Kazakstan. Hoping that the DoJ approves the merger, the oil tycoons decide to sacrifice a few of their front men. Meanwhile, CIA is intriguing against an Arab prince. A former CIA-agent Bob Barnes and an energy analyst Bryan Woodman also get tangled to this devious game. Does this sound amorphous? That's what it is at first, but Syriana is a movie that takes more shape the more you watch it. It's still not a movie for everyone, requiring continuing concentration and some interest towards oil politics. Traffic was a similar, but a much easier film with its smoother pace and color world that was different in every storyline. Syriana instead doesn't make anything easy for the viewer. The plot twists aren't thrashed out and the film jumps from a place to another completely unpredictably. It's a 2-hour political thriller about oil, terrorism, corruption, money and betrayal with a puzzling narrative that both astonishes and fascinates. Once all the plot lines have formed, the film's subtleties are impossible to deny.The acting is solid all the way, but no one really gets to shine since there are so many characters and the plot travels fast. Still, George Clooney delivers a startling performance as the tragic Bob Barnes. He has managed to strip away all that ladies man's charisma that he's famous for. Matt Damon as Bryan Woodman and Jeffrey Wright as lawyer Bennett Holiday hired to investigate the Kazakstan-deal's background are also splendid. Mark Strong, Tim Blake Nelson and Oscar winners William Hurt, Chris Cooper and Christopher Plummer appear in small, shady roles.But what is the film's message? Quite familiar: oil business is cruel and affects many people around the world. It has been heard before, but as long as films this brilliant are made out of it, it doesn't bother. The film's complexity is intentional, but the same complexity makes it fascinating every time. Syriana is an underrated masterpiece that shows how America does business. And that is not beautiful to watch, but endlessly compelling.</fullReview>

An opposite oil company team has a bright lawyer on hand who is digging up this dirt so's they can quash this merger. 		<fullReview>Syriana is a geopolitical thriller film written and directed by Stephen Gaghan. 		<shortDescription>Four movies in one</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie weaves together the stories of four different people: an American financial expert, based in Switzerland, who specializes in energy; a Muslim Pakistani guest worker for an oil company in a fictional Arab country who evolves into a terrorist when losing his job when two oil companies merge; a CIA agent; a legal counsel in a firm whose job it is to handle any political ramifications of the oil company merger. In addition there is an Arab prince, oil company executives, congressmen, and so forth, as well as some people you are never quite sure about. This is a complicated movie whose message seems to be that when it comes to global politics and oil, nothing is simple. The lives of the four principal characters overlap only tangentially and the clever plot construct is that, while the actions of each character has consequences for the others, none has any realization of that. You come away feeling that getting at the full truth behind any geopolitical situation is hopeless, there are just too many moving parts.Nobody comes away looking terribly good, except perhaps the Arab prince. While this is fiction, I felt that it was quite believable. The actors are in fine form and, unusual for this type of film, you see that the characters have personal lives and have to deal with everyday problems like anyone does. You get to know them as people rather than pawns in a game. There would be enough material in the lives of any of the four principals for a full length feature.This film is not a light entertainment; it has important things to say. You are thrown into the middle of events from the beginning; hats off to anyone who comes away with a firm grasp of things after a single viewing. I only came to appreciate what a fine movie this is the second time around.</fullReview>

The tie in with the oil crisis brings together two otherwise very different cultures and shows mostly differences.The discombobulated feeling that the movie originally conveys through non-narrative format becomes wrapped up with the governmental confusion of two clashing countries over oil. 		<shortDescription>Three things</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana is three things.First, it is a very good film. Well written, well acted, thoughtful and it treats its audience as adults, fully able to take on board what it offers them without being spoon-fed mock heroics, non-stop explosions and so on.Second, it is complex. A number of threads interweave and interact, and things done by one element are seen to have consequences as far as others are concerned which are far outside what may have been anticipated.Third, it leaves a nasty taste in the mouth afterwards. This because it so credibly offers a vision of a world in which money - and nothing else - is the prime motivator in westernised society, and its pursuit trumps all other cards. I know that this theme is far from uncommon, but it is rare to see it portrayed on screen so clearly, so accurately, and with such an absence of retribution for those most deserving of it.Highly recommended.</fullReview>

		<date>2010-01-07</date>
		<username>John_Truby</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Horizontal Storytelling</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Stephen Gaghan's Syriana is one of the most ambitious scripts to come out of Hollywood in a long time. His story strategy is a strange combination of showing the audience an extremely big picture while also placing them in extreme ignorance. He tells a very horizontal story, showing many elements and forces working at one time, but also puts the audience in the same position as a cop trying to figure out a crime.Gaghan is clearly within the storytelling tradition of the last hundred years in which the viewer comes to understand over the course of the story. This approach reached its apex in such European films as Last Year at Marienbad and The Conformist. It makes the audience work hard, but the endpoint is supposed to be a deeper learning of the real patterns of the world.Unfortunately, that never happens in Syriana. What comes together at the end is the idea that the powerful of the world conspire together to increase and perpetuate the powers that be. But we know that from the beginning. The specifics of what happens remain confusing and there is almost no emotional completion.When you make the audience work this hard to figure out so many strands, and force them to sit in ignorance for almost the entire film, you had better have a fantastic plot revelation at the end. In effect, if you make them take their medicine, you have to give them a great treat for their effort. But we never get the treat. Gaghan might argue that he is purposely trying to cut against a big Hollywood finish, with everything tied up neatly. But giving the audience a great plot isn't "going Hollywood." It's good writing.Even if you accept this excuse for a flat plot payoff, Gaghan has to justify taking the medicine with something. With an intellectual, multi-strand movie like this, the payoff isn't going to be emotional. It has to be a great thematic revelation. But this too is missing. We know from the beginning that big corporations run the world and get most of what they want. So learning that at the end is not learning anything.Study this script carefully if you want to see the strengths and weaknesses of horizontal storytelling. Perhaps the biggest insight a writer can take from Syriana is: the more characters you track in a story, the harder it is to make an emotional impact on the audience.FOR MORE REVIEWS, please visit www.truby.com</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>gets better if you see it more than once (the old saying, but it's true)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't know if I'll ever think Syriana is a masterpiece or great film or worthy on a top 10 list or other. But it's something that sucks me in when it comes up on TV, and after seeing bits and pieces- following already seeing it twice in the theater- I have a grasp on it, firmly. It's a political drama/thriller about big oil and terrorism and lobbyists and behind-closed-doors negotiating and death and torture and so on and so on. It's confusing, but it's really not so if you pay attention. It's just that Stephen Gaghan's script is so dense that you're bound to loose yourself in the specifics of what's happening when or why or through what channel or whatever (Jeffrey Wright's character's story, arguably, goes through the most to try and get the thinking viewer to pay close watch). But there's also some strong dramatic connections going on, things that bring out the humanity, or the suppression there-of through bigger-than-life business and murder and sadism, that make it worthwhile.Particularly the strongest asset is George Clooney, which he got the Oscar for (albeit as a possible sympathy vote for ditching him on his other two Oscar noms for Good Night and Good Luck); his portrayal is calm and with an underlying sorrow that's crushing at times. This guy's seen so much, and knows likely too much, for him to be kept around long in a government that will sell out anyone for the price of big oil. To see him go through a small scene like that with his character's son, or to see him in a dark movie theater sharing a secret with William Hurt's character, or being tortured, or going for broke in the climax, is exhilarating; his scenes probably ground the film, at best, for the audience. It's everything else that you'll need to try and keep an eye on: the tragedy of Matt Damon's character, a market-watcher in Europe who's transferred to the mideast, and that of Wright's professional who gets in deeper and deeper in corruption, are a little trickier to navigate. And it's frustrating in that, unlike Traffic, it's a more challenging script than that of direction and storytelling; we're never too sure where it's going at times in the mid-section, but to keep engaged is the tricky part even as the script dazzles with its spot-on, mature dialog and little subtle twists (the king's son who doesn't want the power, and then explains to Damon's character why, very good scene).The best thing to do is to go in knowing what to expect, and then take it on the terms of how it goes: an intentionally confounding take on the biggest, most incredulous industry in the world. You might wonder if the "addiction to oil" even means anything. "Corruption," Tim Blake Nelson's character says, very directly and dishearteningly to the point, "is why we win." 7.5/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Plot less matrix of intrigues</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a stylish-looking intrigue thriller evocative of sound bites and headlines from the Middle East near the beginning of the 21st century. Based loosely on CIA operative Robert Baer's memoir, See No Evil: The True Story of a Ground Solder in the CIA's War on Terrorism (2003), the main point of the movie seems to be that our need for oil compromised our efforts to stop terrorism. Or another way to look at this is to say that the CIA and the US government in general failed to make an effective transition from Cold War intelligence operations to the so-called War on Terror.Oil companies conspiring to increase supply and profits, Arabian princes vying to become the next emir, CIA agents sleuthing in dangerous lands, board meetings and cocktail parties with wealthy and influential international players, bombs going off, fear and torture, and a very nice precision rocket launch in the desert to hit exactly the fourth car in a queue are featured. Unfortunately it's the sort of movie that looks a lot better than it plays.Director Stephen Gaghan who wrote the script for Traffic (2000), a drug war thriller in which several story lines are meshed, uses a similar technique here with the unifying factor being oil instead of street drugs. Despite an engaging performance from George Clooney and fine support, especially in the smaller roles (e.g., William Hurt, Christopher Plummer), the formula doesn't work as well mainly because the story goes nowhere. Plot less movies tend to bore the audience since there is no rising action leading to a climax and resolution. Although people die and fortunes wax and wane, the linear story fails to engage our sympathies. I think this might have worked had the focus been on Clooney's character and his struggle to warn the US of the danger of terrorism from the Middle East, a danger that we didn't fully awaken to until 9/11.See this, if you must, for George Clooney who won a Supporting Oscar for his performance.(Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon!)</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A mess!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While Syriana has atmosphere to spare and some good performances, this is one terrible mess of a movie. A lack of exposition or any attempt to explain what is going on and very little about just who is who, the viewer is left to figure out for himself what is going on in all the disparate threads of the story. The dialogue is so sparse, and often so deliberately evasive, that I could never put all the pieces together. My wife totally agreed, which is not that usual for us. How messed up is it? This much: In the scenes spoken in Farsi (or Arabic, or whatever), the subtitles are farcical in their disjointed manner. Often, sentences are not completed, i.e. someone will start a sentence but fail to complete it before beginning another one, or before someone else responds, so that much of the meaning is lost. The wife suggested that this was a defective disk that Netflix sent us, but I doubt it. They're all mass produced after all. It's the movie that is defective. But this method of making movies that leaves too much to the viewer to discern the plot seems part of a modern trend that I find deplorable. It's one thing to give the viewer credit for some intelligence, but quite another to present a puzzle with few clues. This only distracts the viewer from giving full attention to the nuances of the story. I long for the old days of exposition, often by voice-over, to help move the story along without showing everything. For example, take the famously convoluted plot of "The Big Sleep," with Bogart. Compared to "Syriana," that film was a model of comprehension.</fullReview>

		<date>2010-03-12</date>
		<username>James Hitchcock</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A Pot of Message</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Punning on the Biblical story of Esau, who sold his birthright for a mess of pottage, the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon said of H G Wells, whose novels were often marred by heavy-handed propaganda, that he had sold his birthright for a pot of message. I sometimes get the same feeling about George Clooney, who in recent years has used his influence as a Hollywood star to produce and direct a number of films which act as vehicles for his own left-wing opinions. Like "Good Night and Good Luck" (about McCarthyism) and the recent "Men Who Stare at Goats" (about, among other things, Iraq), "Syriana" is a good example.The movie's title (meaning, roughly, "things Syrian") is a misleading one, as none of the action takes place in Syria; indeed, that is one of the few Middle Eastern countries not to be mentioned. (Scriptwriter/director Stephen Gaghan did come up with an explanation of the title, far too convoluted to be repeated here). The film is essentially about petroleum politics and deals with political, economic and social effects of American government policy and of the American oil industry on the Middle East.Roger Ebert described the film as an example of hyperlink cinema because of its use of multiple, parallel story lines, jumping from locations in the U.S., Europe and the Middle East. This type of film-making is nothing new (the late Robert Altman was a noted exponent in films like "Short Cuts"), but it is one that has become increasingly popular in recent years; "Crash" and "Babel" are two other well-known examples from the middle of the last decade.There are essentially four interlinked story lines, centred upon a fictitious oil-rich kingdom in the Persian Gulf. One concerns a proposed merger between two American oil companies, Connex and Killen, which has given rise to misgivings among antitrust regulators at the Department of Justice. The second concerns Bryan Woodman, an energy analyst based in Geneva, Switzerland, whose young son dies in a tragic accident at a party being given by the king of the unnamed country. The third concerns some unemployed Pakistani migrant workers who become involved with an Islamic fundamentalist terrorist group. The fourth deals with Prince Nasir, the king's liberal-minded eldest son, who aims to introduce democratic reforms upon his succession to the throne. For various reasons, the Americans would prefer Nasir's more conservative younger brother to succeed his father, and Bob Barnes, a veteran CIA agent, is sent to the area to organise Nasir's assassination."Syriana" originally had five story lines rather than four but one was cut when it was feared that the film was becoming too complicated. Nevertheless, the plot is still excessively complex and difficult to follow. I am far from being the only person to have remarked upon this aspect of the film; indeed, some have even seen it as a positive virtue, arguing that because the film deals with murky conspiracies, the audience's confusion mimics the confusion of the characters, who find themselves involved in those conspiracies without understanding precisely what is going on. In my experience, however, a film which confuses its audience is also likely to end up alienating them.Another reason why I did not like the film was that I found it too heavily didactic, in common with a number of Clooney's other productions. (Here he stars as Barnes and also acts as executive producer). That does not necessarily mean that I always disagree with his opinions. I share his opposition to the Iraq war and would agree with the viewpoint put forward in "Good Night and Good Luck" that Senator McCarthy's actions were actually damaging to the democratic freedoms he claimed to be defending. Too often, however, he seems to forget that the cinema exists primarily to entertain rather than to lecture.In this case, moreover, the film's basic political thesis seemed over-simplistic and flawed by anti-Americanism. It is essentially arguing that all the problems of the Middle East, from authoritarian governments to terrorism, can be attributed to an American foreign policy driven by the needs of the greedy and corrupt American oil industry, and ignores the many complexities of the real situation. It is never really explained why the Americans want Prince Nasir dead; contrary to what some inveterate America-haters might think, the US government has no objection to democracy per se, and those countries in the region which have introduced democratic reforms along the lines suggested by the Prince, such as Bahrain, Kuwait and the UAE, are often both more stable and more pro-Western than autocracies like Saudi Arabia or Saddam's Iraq. The idea that unemployment and poverty always lie at the root of terrorism is also an oversimplification when one considers that many societies plagued by poverty have not spawned terrorist movements and that many terrorist groups, such as West Germany's Baader-Meinhof Gang, have been made up of university-educated intellectuals who, had they chosen to do so, would have had no difficulty fitting into the affluent bourgeois society they affected to despise.The "hyperlink" style of film-making can be an effective one; "Crash", which won the "Best Picture" Oscar and "Babel", which was nominated for it, are both excellent films; indeed, I would rank "Babel" among the greatest of the present century. It is, however, a style which needs careful handling if the film is not to become over-complex and confusing. "Syriana", which is in nothing like the same class as "Babel" or "Crash", struck me as an example of what can happen when it goes wrong. 4/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Martyrs, Martyrs Everywhere</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Don't watch this movie if you are a person who has no interest in current events, the future of the world, or pondering how we got into the mess in Viet Nam, Iraq, etc., etc., Do watch this movie if you have a hunger for a more mature form of entertainment, such as an evening discussing politics, history, or foreign cultures with your sophisticated friends. The message in this film, at least the message I got, doesn't pound you in the face like one from an old Schwarzenegger film. It doesn't have you clinging to the edge of the seat like one of the multitude of bloody, camp horror flicks. It also doesn't warm your heart like a silly romance. What it does is sneak up on you. When "Syriana" ended, I said to my husband, "Okay...So what was THAT about? They sure didn't put much effort into character development." But, half an hour later, my mind was still tugging at what I had seen as loose threads, pulling on first one and then another. An hour later, my mind had put together the message which I took from the movie, which was: "There's so much talk about the Middle East and their martyrs. We talk about how nutty it is to sacrifice yourself for a cause. Yet, we all have martyrs. Bob Barnes, Bryan Woodman, Prince Nasir, and the actual martyr all have beliefs that they are willing to put themselves on the line for. Some risk their own lives. Some risk the lives of their families. Interestingly, even the most committed of us usually see the other guys cause as being the one not worth a sacrifice; we don't believe "they" are as committed to their principles as "we" are. For the last three days, parts of "Syriana" have popped into my thoughts, helping me to see how the forces at work in the plot of "Syriana" are modeled after real life forces shaping our politics today.As for the actors, I've been a Clooney fan since "Roseanne" but I think this was his best work. I actually forgot he was George Clooney and began thinking of him as Bob Barnes for a while. After growing up in LA, it takes some doing to overcome my cynicism and transport me into the land of "Hollywood." Way to go, Clooney! Bryan Woodman would have been my pick for the least developed character of the movie, but when I "got it" the next day, I realized this was actually part of the character. There are some questions in the audience's mind at the end of the movie about Woodman and had Matt Damon overplayed this part, they wouldn't have been there and the movie wouldn't have been as suspenseful.Prince Nasir, a man of integrity, interested in advancing his countries industrial and societal future won my heart. Alexander Siddig put across a sincerity that made me fell in love with the Prince. (If I was only 20 years younger!) If I could only tell you how many times I yelled "Get out of the car!" I thought it was quite the accomplishment that Siddig's acting showed that the prince loved and respected his father, but had a strong enough character not to back down when he knew he was right.I can't list all of the actors and their accomplishments here because there were so many. I was totally lost by the middle of the movie because there were so many characters and several subplots. My husband, who watched it twice, was able to keep up with it better the second time around. But, he DID watch it twice, which is an indication that it is a movie worthy of watching again and again.So, as I said, if you are interested in current events, politics, history, and/or cultural values, this is a must-see movie! If you only enjoy airhead entertainment, this one isn't for you. But, if you are in that latter group and miss "Syriana," you've missed one awesome movie!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Brave effort. But no cigar.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Years ago now, John Reith said what he figured the mission of the British Broadcasting Corporation to be: "to inform, educate, and entertain." "Syriana" doesn't bother with the last of those ambitions and, given its subject matter, there's no reason why it should.As for the bits about informing and educating though, it's in a muddle from the get-go, never able to manage both and, sometimes, unable to manage either.Its strengths are that it remains resolutely apolitical throughout. And that it shuns showbiz in preference for the cerebral.But its weakness -- and it's a huge weakness -- is that this pretty awesome display of cinematic brain power is ultimately only comprehendable by its creator.The separate story lines are not a problem in themselves. The story lines as and of themselves though. . . Let's try this: what connection did George Clooney's character have with Christopher Plummer's character and why did he confront him and threaten the murder of his family -- no, don't answer that yet; what was Clooney doing, flailing around in the desert with a road map prior to being zapped by a US missile -- no, don't answer that yet;what was the reason for the antagonistic relationship between the law firm investigator and his father, a relationship that culminated in the door-closing coda -- don't answer that, either;who was responsible for, and who died, in the exploding car after Clooney's character did or did not sell US missiles to, well, whoever? Answers can be made now on the basis, but ONLY on the basis, of the on-screen narrative.Not viewer presumption.Because if we're going to enter an era of cinema when every viewer has to spend most of a movie attributing to characters motives, actions, back-stories and relationships which have never been furnished on-screen then I guess it's time to stay home and do crosswords instead.Much is made of the movie's strengths in many a post here, but the generosity of spirit shown can hardly do anyone any favours. I've yet to see answers to the questions raised above -- questions asked deliberately, too, because they mark the convergence, rather than separation, of story lines, the points at which the intersection of characters provides illumination and explanation.Bottom line: the oil business is dirty, the geo-politics that enshroud it are impenetrable, and terrorism's recruiting ground is to be found in terrain where the young are left without roots, without hope, and without a future.Unfortunately. . . we already know that.So although 'Syriana' was brave to tackle all three issues, at the end of 2 hours running time, the oil business is still dirty, geo-politics are still opaque, terrorism is still terrorism and all that's happened is that cinema has somehow managed to make everything even more, rather than less, impenetrable.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>That's what I felt after waisting 2 hours and 4 bucks on this rental.Syriana thinks it's has a plot, it's apparently 4 stories that are somehow connected, or so the promotional tagline would make you believe that.We have a lawyer who investigates some shaddy business with a merger, a CIA operative who sold some guys missiles but it all went wrong, a financial expert who gets a job as a consultant for an arabian prince, especially after his son dies from shock while plunging into a pool who just happened to be from the father of said arabian prince. 		<username>tnrcooper</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Pretty good comprehensive look at oil industry</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's hard to write The Definitve Movie About The Oil Industry. There are so many angles one can take and if one has an inquisitive mind, one might not be able to limit oneself to discussing one part of the industry and its effects on the world. That has never been a deterrent to Stephen Gaghan though. He wrote "Traffic" which took a similar look at the very complex issue of immigration. He did that very very well, in my opinion, and he's done a comparable, if somewhat more generic job, with Syriana. I don't think the meaning of the term Syriana is ever given although, as a guess, it would seem to be a fictionalized term for a fictional, universalized Arab republic. This gives the movie an accessibility that allows for a simple canvas on which to pain an image of a world gone mad, largely defined by the vicissitudes and anomalies of the oil industry. Gaghan wrote "Traffic" based on work by former CIA agent Robert Baer but, distinctively from "Traffic", he also directed this movie. He addresses the question of accessibility to oil via two Saudi princes, Meshar Al-Subaai (Akbar Kurtha) and Nasir Al-Subaai (Alexander Siddig), and who stand to rule the country and might decide the direction of large supplies of oil. Perhaps somewhat overly simplistically in this film, one of the Saudi princes, Nasir envisions a more equitable distribution of, and ethical use of, oil. His reckless younger brother Nasir seems like a conniving, irresponsible party animal with only money and little responsibility, in mind. For me, the contrast between these two characters seemed a little pat and simplistic. It is as though one side of Gaghan's brain was telling him show how the world COULD be with a more equitable energy policy (even if it's as unlikely as Paris Hilton partying with Stephen Hawking), and the other side is telling him, no, tell the truth-or at least the much much much more likely outcome (like the certainty of a losing season for the Kansas City Royals every season). That said, the other threads in the film I found very interesting and intriguing; indeed, the thread about the brothers, while their characters may have seemed a bit too sharply drawn, reveals possible differences in how oil revenues might be apportioned and suggest a more equitable energy policy in the world.The story is also told from the point of view of an oil analyst named Bryan Woodman (a typically accomplished Matt Damon) and the toll his close ties to the industry take on his ostensibly objective TV analysis. There is a rather feebly constructed sub-plot also in which the (at least according to the tale woven by the film) good father Woodman is held accountable for seemingly unconnected family tragedies, supposedly on account of his busy schedule working in the oil industry. The film does not establish that he is a poor father, indeed, he is depicted as a model father, if somewhat busy. Therefore it seems a little unreasonable to attribute blame for some things which do not seem related to his work in the oil industry, or even likely for him to have done. Any person in any industry can become too ensconced in work and fail to meet their obligations at home.Also playing a prominent role in The Definitive Movie About The Oil Industry is the government bureaucrat (George Clooney as Bob Barnes) who becomes aware of improprieties in the US Defense Dept. As a result of his assertiveness, he is assigned to a less politically sensitive matter where his conscience is tested. Also covered in The Definitive Movie About The Oil Industry to a more minor degree are the workings of company politics at a large oil company in scenes very well played by Christopher Plummer as a sleazy oil executive and Christopher Cooper as a high-powered oil company CEO. Perhaps distinguishing himself above all the other performances in this movie, however, is Jeffrey Wright as a government lawyer who is supposed to be settling an oil lawsuit on terms more favorable to consumers but has sabotaged the deal to be more favorable to big oil companies. He is playing both sides of the fence very well and his subterfuge seems to have slid under the radar. Wright portrays a character so bland, so seemingly dull, that one would not sense his tendency to wrong people. Yet he does so, and very confidently. He has concocted an image which is almost beyond reproach and seemingly very honorable.In speaking facetiously about this being a definitive movie, I am not criticizing the movie but merely having a bit of fun with it. It is a very good movie, very well directed, and Gaghan does a fabulous job at weaving and connecting some quite disparate threads. With fine performances in particular from Damon, Cooper, Plummer, and Wright, this is an intriguing and complex reflection on the intricacies and far-reaching effects of the huge influence of the oil industry in our world.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Complex but ultimately rewarding movie that deliverers.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>No doubt that "Syriana" is a difficult movie to watch. You have to keep paying attention at every moment in the movie if you don't want to lose track of things. But those who have the patience and will to keep watching this movie will be rewarded with a thought provoking and effective movie that will leave you thinking afterward.Best thing about this movie is that it basically follows four different plot lines and characters but it really doesn't feel like four separate and different stories at all. The movie feels as a complete whole and is consistent during its entire running time. All the stories have one thing in common, they are more or less about one and the same subject; oil. This might be the reason why the movie feels like one. The movie is called "Traffic"-'light' for a good reason. It's made in the same style and terms of realistic storytelling- and character treatment. No wonder, the movie is directed by Stephen Gaghan who wrote "Traffic" and one of the executive producers on this movie is Steven Soderbergh, who directed "Traffic". It sort of sounds strange to call this movie a 'light' version of "Traffic", since this movie in my opinion is far more complex (even though it focuses on far less character and plot lines) and focuses on a even more difficult and delicate subject."Traffic" taught us that the war on drugs can't be won, "Syriana" shows us that the lust for oil can never be stopped and the movie shows the direct consequences of it. The movie is about the Western and mostly American corruption and naivety. The movie shows how this affects the Middle-East and its population and how that more or less directly hits back at the Western world. It's a sort of vicious circle. We want more and more oil for lower prices but we eventually pay a far higher price than just money for it.Kudos to Stephen Gaghan and the rest of the cast &amp; crew to have to guts to make such a politically sensitive but relevant movie.The movie gets carried by its excellently playing cast. This probably the best role of George Clooney I have ever seen him in. He deserved his Oscar for this movie, even though his role was far smaller than I expected. Matt Damon might be a bit out of place in this movie. I don't regard him as 'mature' enough yet to play such heavy and serious roles. I would had preferred an older or a totally unknown actor for his role. Among the supporting cast are Christopher Plummer, Amanda Peet, the always great Chris Cooper, William Hurt and Tim Blake Nelson. Not all of their roles seem relevant enough but nevertheless their presence still adds to the class of this movie.A sort of an essential movie to watch, at least if you're open for a complex but confronting and direct movie, about a sensitive and not much lighted subject.8/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/</fullReview>

		<date>2007-06-18</date>
		<username>zardoz-13</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Skip This Movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Watching the new current events thriller "Syriana" (**1/2 out of ****) is like attending a graduate level foreign affairs seminar and listening to the professor drone on in monotone about the myriad Machiavellian machinations of U.S. diplomacy in the Middle East. Mind you, this kind of complex, global, political, and socio-economic history might make fascinating fodder in the right hands. In the wrong hands, however, it is like having sawdust stuffed into your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. Ostensibly based on real-life CIA agent Robert Baer's 2003 memoir "See No Evil," this well-intentioned but muddled George Clooney &amp; Matt Damon pseudo-documentary examines an unsavory Rubic's cube of intrigue between greedy a Texas oil corporation and shady government nation building in the Persian Gulf with all the subtlety of a sledgehammer. Anybody who has studied American diplomacy in the Middle East since the 1950s, or for that matter Central America, won't be shocked by writer &amp; director Stephen Gaghan's sensational expose. Best known for his Oscar winning "Traffic" (2000) screenplay, Gaghan tackles subject matter considerably more controversial than he handled in his freshman effort, the ably crafted 2002 Katie Holmes thriller "Abandon." The only thing surprising about "Syriana" is the artful way that Gaghan dodges attaching odium to either Democrats or Republicans.Writer &amp; director Stephen Gaghan tries to shoe-horn too many characters and too much plot into this R-rated, 126 minute melodrama that covers a variety of themes: Middle Eastern terrorism, torture, suicide bombers, American corporate-level mergers, cultural disparities, the CIA at its villainous worst pedaling illegal arms and assassinating foreign nobles, the death of an innocent child, the global struggle between the U.S. and China over ownership and control of oil. Four characters stand out in this abundance of intrigue: world-weary, veteran CIA operative Bob Barnes (George Clooney of "Ocean's Twelve"), preppy energy analyst Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon of "The Bourne Identity"), idealistic Middle Eastern Prince Nasir Al-Subaai (Alexander Siddig of "Kingdom of Heaven") and scheming corporate attorney Bennett Holiday (Jeffrey Wright of "Shaft"). "Syriana" opens as Clooney's portly CIA agent has just sold two elite weapons to terrorists, but learns to his horror that one winds up in the hands of a splinter group that Barnes knows nothing about. When he reports this revelation to his superiors, the CIA shrugs it off with little concern. Meanwhile, after the accidental death of one of his two sons at a party hosted by a Middle Eastern nobleman, Bryan becomes an adviser to Nasir Al-Subaai. Nasir wants to usher his backward country into the 21st century with equal rights for women and pays Woodman for his advice. In yet another subplot, Bennett brokers a deal between Prince Nasir's father, Emir Hamed Al-Subaai (Nadim Sawalha of "Sphinx") and a prominent Texas oil company that plans a merger with another oil company. Before the Texas oil corporation can cement the deal with the Emir, Bennett has to negotiate with the U.S. Justice Department, so that the merger receives the Attorney General's blessing. Predictably, bodies pile up along the way as everybody struggles to obtain what they want for their own selfish ends. The conflict that lies at the heart of the oil merger is an anonymous Middle Eastern kingdom where the good guy Prince (Siddig) refuses to court American interests and the bad guy Prince Meshal Al-Subaai(newcomer Akbar Kurtha), more engrossed in his own jet-setting lifestyle, wants to accommodate America interests. Again, Gaghan leaps back and forth with dizzying rapidity among these multiple subplots. We watch two minutes of this and two minutes of that, all lensed with hand-held cameras that impart a persuasive newsreel authenticity. Indeed, "Syriana" drums up a lot of potential but is so swamped with cynicism that only super na?ve people will be shocked by its revelations. For example, the slimy oil company tycoons claim that they have everybody's best interests at heart when the only heart that they have is their own wallet. The U.S. Attorney General's Office refuses to condone an improper corporate merger unless it can indict a couple of sacrificial lambs in the process to make itself look good. Of course, the CIA strives to keep the Middle East destabilized enough so that the oil rich countries will have to rely on U.S. support. Another plot shows renegade Islamic terrorists preying on suicidal simpletons to fulfill their own murderous agenda. Essentially, the average American moviegoer is supposed to wade into this morass of amorality and walk out crying foul. Sample any foreign affairs books by distinguished historians such as John Lewis Gaddis, Michael J. Hogan, William Appleman Williams or Walter LaFeber, and you'll discover the unsavory realities of American foreign policy since the Eisenhower administration through to contemporary presidents. Some people will applaud the producers of "Syriana" for making an ambitious thought-provoking film that doesn't pander to lowest common denominator interests. Admirable as their efforts are, the "Syriana's" producers seem to have forgotten what makes a good film.Gaghan's chief problem is his obsession with message at the expense of compelling drama. Hopelessly preachy as it is, "Syriana" is going to stump the average moviegoer rather than stun them into a sense of consciousness about the corrupt amoral world around them. Indeed, we do need more movies like "Syriana" to expose the evils that our government engineers in the name of national interests. Unfortunately, the problem that "Syriana" has is the problem that afflicts too many typical or atypical Hollywood products--of alienating more often than involving audiences.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2006-03-04</date>
		<username>Chris_Docker</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Socially responsible film-making of the exciting kind</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Good fiction has one major advantage over documentary - it allows us to say, "What if . . ." Documentary may allow us to challenge 'facts', but fiction creates hypothetical scenarios of endless ingenuity that can free us to explore the sense of right and wrong from myriad points of view. One of the characteristics of the mature intellect may even be the ability to encompass many perspectives, to use multiple paradigms, before attaching great weight to any particular position. For fiction to work in this way, it needs to encompass realistically many sides of a dilemma, and ask more questions than answers. As a modern day global thriller, Syriana, rather than trying to push home a particular agenda, ekes out justifiable reasons behind the actions of a multitude of differing individuals, governments, cultures, corporate bodies and institutions that all have one thing in common - the high stakes and power plays flowing from the procurement and availability of oil. Its interweaving stories in many locations force us to try and make sense of an international tragedy facing our planet in what President Bush has described as the 'addiction to oil'.Using facts from a work of non-fiction, 'See No Evil', Syriana starts in Iran with George Clooney almost losing control over the movement of some armaments (although not essential, a mental map of the world and some familiarity with relevant world affairs will greatly enhance enjoyment of this movie). A few minutes later, in a street in Tehran, there is a casual and almost unconnected explosion that destroys any illusion of this being a nice, comfortable spy movie. It was at this point that I decided Bad Things were probably going to happen in the film. Repeatedly. It already had an almost clinical realism suggesting no storyline would be sweetened.Writer Stephen Gaghan takes a similar multifaceted approach to the one he used in his award-winning Traffic, empathetically tracing the lives of people from very different worlds as they interconnect and converge on a single theme. Clooney, as a veteran CIA operative, confronts various dilemmas in trying to do his job well in the face of interference, as well as personal crises, survival under torture, and trying to make a positive difference in a messed-up world. His bosses look at a more global picture but are frequently hampered. Potentially sensible, civilised developments in the tradition-laden world of the Gulf princes could alter the world balance-of-power in a damaging way. The free enterprise and profitable (if questionable) merger of two oil concerns creates apprehension in Washington and among energy experts, but also impacts the lives of migrant workers in a way no-one considers in the face of more pressing worries. Traders meanwhile look at instability premiums.Clooney's son has typical university student angst, righteously (if simplistically) accusing his parents of being professional liars. Energy consultant Matt Damon and his wife Amanda Peet find their relationship increasingly strained as his professional commitments become more dangerous. Their son provides a rare moment of comic relief at a family vegetarian breakfast by demanding 'pig bacon'.Approaching hefty problems on every level but also reminding us of the human commitment, energises Syriana in a way few movies dream possible. We can identify with most of the characters or at least admit their reality. None are perfect, and all are prey to the greed or corruption of others, whether it is a conflicted businessman or an uneducated and penniless youth living in the shadow of a Middle-Eastern oil-field. Whatever your politics or beliefs, Syriana is sure to cast doubt on them, but in not taking sides it makes us aware of aspects we might not otherwise have considered.Minutely researched and executed, the film poses stark questions that are too uncomfortable generally to even ask, and then only offers inescapable geographical facts or hard truths that politicians might genuinely want to shield us from. Deputy National Security Adviser (Viola Davis) tries to simplify it: "India is now our ally. Even China will be an ally. Everybody between Morocco and Pakistan is the problem. Failed states and failed economies, but Iran is a natural cultural ally of the U.S. The Persians do not want to roll back the clock to the 8th century. I see students marching in the streets. I hear Khatami making the right sounds. And what I'd like to know is if we keep embargoing them on energy, then someday soon are we going to get a nice, secular, pro-Western, pro-business government?" Agent Clooney, from hard experience, tries to disabuse her of such wishful thinking but is dexterously sidelined in favour of People Who Have Answers.Syriana is a venture of Participant Productions, a company that aims to make socially relevant films, which also have broad appeal, and it is the most accomplished offering of the company to date. An action-packed but critically intelligent thriller, it doesn't take sides or offer solutions, but the effect is both breathtaking and harrowing. Its main source material, 'See No Evil', could suggest not only a hiding from unpalatable truth, but even a desire to see good in all actions ('everyone believes they are doing the right thing when they do it') approach that lends credibility to diverse points of view and, although George Clooney is a self-confessed left-wing liberal, his film, ironically, might even suggest that Bush's memorable truism could be the most revolutionary policy statement of that presidency. Our imaginary country of Syriana is a place where we can all let our imaginations run free to plumb the quagmires of human tragedy associated with the oil industry.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>An interesting geopolitical thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Set in the murky worlds of the oil industry and Middle Eastern politics this film follows various characters caught up when a US company fears losing a vital contract in an unnamed Arabian country on the Persian Gulf. The Emir is preparing to hand power to one of his sons; the elder, Prince Nasir, wants to make their country more liberal and believes that selling to the Chinese at a higher price will make this possible; his brother is more interested in his personal fortune and will happily sell to the Americans then buy US weaponry with the profits if his own pockets are sufficiently lined. Into this situation we see CIA operative Bob Barnes who is concerned when a missile sold as part of a sting operation goes missing; his bosses are more concerned about the state of the oil industry and wants him to assassinate Prince Nasir? a plan that doesn't go well and nearly gets him killed. Meanwhile Geneva based energy analyst Bryan Woodman gets a job working with the Prince as he plans to create a post-oil economy for the country. Back in the US lawyer Bennett Holiday is given the task of making the oil company's activities seem legal? even if it means sacrificing some senior people to the law. The final plot thread follows a young Pakistani migrant who gets radicalised after losing his job in the gulf.As the film progresses it switches between these plot strands; each part of the larger picture but almost totally separate as far as the characters are concerned. The idea of having protagonists who are for the most part totally unaware of each other is interesting although it does make it imperative that you play close attention to what is happening. If one does that this is a gripping thriller which manages to provide some surprises although as the end approaches most viewers will be fairly certain that it won't end well and business will progress as usual. The cast do a solid job making us believe in their characters. These notably include George Clooney who plays the less than glamorous Barnes, Matt Damon who plays Woodman and Alexander Siddig who plays Prince Nasir. The film does not shy away from depicting Western actions in the Middle East as self-serving and hypocritical; something that can be uncomfortable viewing at times. Don't expect lots of action; what action there is is fairly matter of fact or disturbing rather than exciting.</fullReview>

		<username>eric262003</username>

		<shortDescription>An Enjoyable Film, But Crams Too Much</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Written and directed by Stephen Gaghan, "Syriana" stands among one of the top political thrillers of 2005. This complex tale features the trials and tribulations of the oil industry between the Texas oil conglomerates and the Gulf emirs, Middle Eastern terrorists and smart lawyers, the CIA Agents and the Iranian liberation organizations, the fear of China uprising economically, the disdain of regulation, shady business dealing mixed with botched missile attacks, it has everything you would expect in an enthralling political drama.From the guy who wrote the 2001 Oscar winning film "Traffic", Gahgan wrote the script inspired from the memoirs of former CIA Agent Robert Baer and the title derives from the representation of a reconfigured Middle East. Sure it comes as no surprise that Gaghan thinks that the oil trade is synonymous to selling dope. There's shady deals mixed with exciting thrills and if one error is made, it'll be that one error that you wish you never had committed. With the huge ensemble of talented thespians, the international globe-jumping, and the scintillating film's depth stands alone like no other. Much like the ever powerful film "The Interpreter", "Syriana" is surely going to make your brain active. Running just over the two hour mark, this film had enough fortitude to have lasted a half hour longer.Looked pudgy and bearded, George Clooney is Oscar material and has that bear-like instincts in him as grizzled CIA Agent Bob Barnes who's mission is to go to Iran and put a stop towards illegal trafficking in the Middle East. Matt Damon is equally poignant as a giddy young energy analyst named Bryan Woodman who reluctantly cashes in a family incident to form an alliance with a Persian Prince Nasir (Alexander Siddig). Jeffrey Wright has an engaging subplot as the debonair Washington DC attorney Bennett Holiday who has his hands full (in oil that is) as he's about to propose a monstrous merger with a top oil company while shutting out the Gulf, while Jimmy Pope's (Chris Cooper) oil company Killen has been bribed to get drilling rights in the country of Kazakhstan.Not one subplot conveys any kind of bias towards Americans just like not every Middle Eastern civilian is entirely evil. So therefore it refrains from having some sort of Republican agenda going for it. In a unbiased perspective, I'm given the impression that Prince Nasir is the incumbent good guy while Mr. Holiday's superior Dean Whiting (Christopher Plummer) is a merciless antagonist. The morality between the characters in this story are not set in stone. What truly embodies "Syriana" is to try to decipher the sincerity with the three leading stars (Damon, Clooney and Wright). But even though your brain is getting good exercise the confusing subplots is also its main liability. The points of view depicted in this movie are so varied it is enough to give anyone a migraine and we have very little time to decode it.There are times when the characters were under-directed. It's hard to understand whether Barnes was a decoy or a hardened operative or a bit of both. Is Woodman a glorified opportunist or an incentive idealist? And what does Bennett Holiday have on his agenda? Is he a shady attorney with a passive-aggressive demeanour, or is he just corporate human puppet just out to make a huge profit and to please his superiors? And sure like most political thrillers, character development outweighs action, the activity is virtually micro. Agent Barnes is an enigmatic intellectual for hitting the narratives worldwide."Syriana" can be both depicted as both provocative and at times a bit out of place. However, Gaghan is less interested in heroics and more focused on the system as much as it can be unraveled. His visions are more philosophical than they are obvious. We do feel that at any moment, one country will be bombed and that sooner enough the big story will finally materialize through the more smaller subplots.From Gaghan's skewed framing, awkward editing, and overwhelming Stedicam, add more salt to the wounds of the movie's jilted narrative. And while underneath the chaos, never once does Gaghan ever try to insult its audience. Gaghan assumes we'll get the historical gist when names a Mossadegh comes to mind or the conspicuous self-serving Zen monks certain characters come onto the scene.Even though this movie has moral feelings to it, its intentions are at times quite superficial. But no matter what this movie is anything but glib or flaky.</fullReview>

		<username>samvadi parthasarathi</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A landmark film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Lasting Impression: Every now and then a film arrives that demands that it not merely be watched, but studied.Stephen Gaghan's effort is astonishing in it's breadth and depth. The Source: Based on ex-CIA operative Bob Baer's heartfelt autobiography "See No Evil", Gaghan embarked on an extensive research, accompanied by Mr. Baer himself, to meet the real people in the geo-political game of energy security (read Arab Oil). Those who have read the book will realize that a small part of the book forms just one strand in the film. The Outline: The major strand is the purported merger of two US oil giants, after one is kicked out of the Gulf, in favour of a Chinese consortium, by the ageing Emir's ambitious son, and the other, smaller company that has acquired lucrative oil fields elsewhere. This politico-legal-corporate strand of the story is led by a lawyer of a reputed firm that is providing legal advice to the merger. The next strand is a young immigrant Pakistani worker in the Gulf oil fields, who is out of a job because the Americans got kicked out. It portrays his gradual radicalization, for lack of a job, by a wily local Imam. The third strand is of a successful Industry Analyst(Matt Damon), based in Europe, who ends up tragically working for the Emir's son and is unwittingly involved in his power struggle. The final strand is the CIA operative(George Clooney), a dedicated field agent who gets trapped in all of this, by his own side. The Technicality: Each strand is fleshed out convincingly, and through some really smart editing, the film connects keeps pace with all the strands. Alexandre Desplat's score is haunting and evocative in it's simplicity, and very appropriately employed. The Takeaway: Essentially, it is a timeless parable about how smart/powerful people will use situations, systems and underlings in a matter-of-fact way to achieve their aims - whether personal gain or the greater good or both - there is no moral squeamishness about it. At the same time it is a poignant fable about the universality of "a decent chance at life" and lengths that ordinary people will go for it, before losing their way, maybe.The Impact: This film will not shock you like a Spielberg, or make you squirm like Oliver Stone - but will embed itself deeply within your psyche as a disconcerting shard of truth. For all the privileges we enjoy - someone, somewhere pays the price - and it's more than it should be. But then, there is no other way!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Hazy but Solid</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana does not contain the action scenes you might associate with George Clooney or Matt Damon and its split narratives do not lead to a life-affirming conclusion. Nor will it cut any ice with patriots wedded to the idea of America's role as the liberator of the Middle East. But none of this makes it a bad film.True, it can be a mite confusing. It took me a while to work out what, or who, George Clooney's CIA agent was meant to be doing when he is sent to Beirut. But momentary confusion does little to obscure the function of the film - a masterclass in American foreign policy in the Middle East.The film, wisely, does not mention Iraq. To do so would enter a debate that has become so polarised as to be meaningless. It gives a broader picture, and by doing so exposes the paradox in American (and British) policy towards the Middle East. While we in the West do believe that democracy is a way of stabilising countries and bringing them into the global economy, it is a double-edged sword. If Arab leaders are elected, they have legitimacy in the eyes of their people. The more legitimacy they have, the less they must rely on Western military support to prop up their regimes.What Syriana illustrates so eloquently is that when it comes down to a choice, America would rather have despotic Arab leaders it can push around than liberal-minded reformists who would be free to negotiate oil deals with, say, China. It is not a choice without consequences, the film argues. Which leader, the despot or the reformist, is more likely to preside over a society that fosters terrorists? The film lets you make up your own mind.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>This movie was recommended to me by a political analyst. Since I love political thrillers, without any doubt I took the DVD and saw it. Maybe my expectations were too high, but a movie with superb actors and a genius director should have been a lot better. This movie has three different story lines. If we observe all of them separately we will find great political/social/crime stories. Put them together and the result is not so pleasing. Why is that so? Every story tried to present a complete sociological structure of it's main character. I found myself constantly trying to keep up with the movie, thinking: "Where did we leave of in this story?" "What happened here?" etc. In this constant focus shift, I did not receive the complete image of some crucial characters. Another problem with this movie is that it has almost no music. It gave the movie a dull and even more slow-paced feature than it actually has. Apart from these big flaws, the acting is superb, certain scenes are so powerful that they stick with one long after the movie is over, and it has a great message. It's not easy to watch, it's complex and at times difficult to understand, but it really is worth the time and money.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The dramatic thriller, Syriana, is a telling story of how the power of the oil industry?particularly, the United States' dependence on it?affects the world and many lives.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The dramatic thriller, Syriana, is a telling story of how the power of the oil industry?particularly, the United States' dependence on it?affects the world and many lives. The story provides an account of the interrelated lives of key people/groups: the Emirate's foreign minister, Prince Nasir (Alexander Siddig), successor to his father's position as Emir, gives drilling rights to a company in China, which takes the supply away from the United States; a major U.S. energy company, Connex, loses this oil connection in the Middle East to China and enters into a shady deal with a smaller U.S. company, Killen, which has ties to oil in Kazakhstan; a lawyer, Bennett Holiday (Jeffrey Wright), is assigned to investigate the Connex/Killen merger only to discover a hint of corruption; the Pakistani immigrant, Wasim Khan (Mazhar Munir) who loses his job at the oil company once Connex is outbid by a Chinese company; the energy analyst, Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon) becomes Prince Nasir's economic adviser to bring reform to Nasir's country; and CIA agent, Bob Barnes (George Clooney), who is familiar with the Middle East from previous missions soon realizes the shadiness of the U.S. government.The film's theme?the oil dependency of the United States and the social problems it causes, which creates a ripple effect?captures the greed, the corruption, and the deceitfulness one natural resource, oil, poses on those who come in contact with it. These factors all stem from the removal of oil supply to the United States, which was believed to be extremely detrimental to the U.S. economy. From Prince Nasir establishing a business relationship with China down to Wasim being introduced to a powerful weapon, no one knew how significant their actions would be to the world. At certain times, the theme often reminds you of another of Writer/Director Stephen Gaghan's films, Traffic, where social problems?the war on drugs?connected independent stories and involved corruption and exploitation.The different film techniques?lighting and rough-grain film stock?were used appropriately throughout the film, and helped compliment the film's theme by providing depth, dismal moods, and a quick capture of reality. For example, the low lighting used in the meeting between Connex and Killen representatives sets the scheming and somber mood of the scene, as well as the dark lighting set in the debrief meeting between agent Bob Barnes, his superiors, and the CLI?Committee for the Liberation of Iran?which creates a more dramatic image for the importance of the meeting. Finally, the rough-grain film stock created the rough and grainy image with harsh contrasts for the bomb explosion set off by Bob Barnes as he swiftly walked away from the scene.In conclusion, Gaghan effectively communicates the theme of the United States' dependence on oil and its effects by focusing on the intertwined lives of its characters throughout the film. His gritty filming techniques and character development are successful in making Syriana a complicated work that draws the viewer into its focus.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Bad world</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Stephen Gaghan's film 'Syriana' is certainly ambitious, offering us a complex, intelligent and ultimately unhappy view of the politics of oil. In a large ensemble cast, George Clooney is perhaps the lead in an atypically unglamourous role, playing an overweight, rogue U.S. government agent. The story seems complex enough to fill an entire television series, and is at times confusing; rather than spelling out every incident of plot, the film instead samples each strand at key intervals, conveying a sense of development without telling us exactly how it has happened. By the end of the movie, one is finally involved enough to care; but it's a slow process, and what is sacrificed is the chance of real sympathy for any of the characters; while I normally dislike heroes of pure motive, there has to be an "in" to a story; without one, the take home message fails to amount to much more than "it's a bad world".</fullReview>

Hollywood libs probably take it as an article of faith that the CIA assassinates enlightened Arab princes all the time.)The final thing you need to know is that the movie's Muslim suicide bomber is -- as I think one of the IMDb commenters here described him -- a handsome doe-eyed waif, shy, dutiful, hardworking, a loving son who becomes a suicide bomber mainly because he's out of work, hungry, and desperate. He's a Sympathetic Suicide Bomber, you see. 		<username>sddavis63 (revsdd@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Believable, But Also Dull, Lifeless And Passionless</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie attempts to document a fictitious attempt by the combined forces of the US government and a giant US multinational oil company to manipulate the politics of a Middle Eastern country (presumably Saudi Arabia) in order to ensure the supply of oil to America. Essentially, the Emir is preparing to hand over power, but his eldest son, who would normally succeed him, has signed a deal to sell oil to China. This son is a political moderate (even modern and democratic, favouring an elected Parliament and votes for women) but the US opposes him because of the China deal, and instead seeks to arrange (through a variety of surrogates) for his less competent and less democratic (but pro-American) younger brother to take power. The story is fictional, but plausible - which is the greatest strength of the film. It's believable pretty much all the way through. From what I had heard of the movie I was expecting to find a slam of some sort against the Bush administration, but that wasn't really evident here. It seemed more to be making the point that - whoever is supposedly in power in Washington - it's really oil that rules. That point is well made, and the complexity of doing business in the Middle East is also made evident. The problem with this is that it never really seemed to hit its stride. At one point, Bob (George Clooney) - apparently a CIA agent - is told that his experience is "narrow but thick." In other words, his whole career has been spent focusing on this one part of the world, so he knows a lot about this issue, but little about anything else. I'd describe the movie as the opposite: wide but shallow. It introduces too much. It jumps from Washington to Beirut to Spain to Iran to Saudi Arabia to Switzerland and back and forth, but - to me - there seemed to be little depth offered. We just get a bare sense of the behind the scenes machinations going on with little substance. Add to that the rather dull, lifeless and passionless flow to the movie (which matches my general attitude to George Clooney's acting in pretty much everything I've ever seen him in - I'm not a fan) and what you end up with may be a believable story, but it's a believable story that really isn't that interesting to watch unfold. It's no better than a 4/10.</fullReview>

		<username>dougdoepke</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Jigsaw in Half-Light</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As an expose of power politicking around the oil business, the movie is only mildly successful. But then, I don't believe the film was intended as an expose. That would have required a more coherent, more focused narrative than the fragmentary mosaic we're confronted with. Instead of a judgmental result, we're presented with a dark panorama of bits and pieces that catch the characters on the fly and refuse to draw conclusions about what they do. The screenplay appears to say that in the amoral world of power politics there are only far-flung interests and the people promoting them, and nothing else significant enough to include. In this case the amoral cast includes the CIA, an oil analyst, a high-powered law firm, Hezbollah, suicide bombers, oil sheiks, Texas wildcatters, the Chinese, corporate oil men, and a motley assortment of other shady characters. If this seems unwieldy, it is. And so is the movieObviously, the intensely allusive style where little is explained forces a viewer to pay close attention, that is, if he doesn't give up first. Now, I realize that this is a highly sophisticated way of sketching an international panorama that likely defies traditional narrative, and further, that intellectually inclined viewers are likely impressed with the unyielding approach. My reservation is that the movie succeeds, but only within a narrow intellectual frame. More importantly, the topic shapes up as simply too important to be confined to an esoteric frame. I don't mind filling-in some dots, but I don't want to lose the picture because the dots are too few and too scattered. The movie ultimately suffers from trying to do too much with too little.</fullReview>
	</review>
