		<date>2006-06-25</date>
		<username>babyfishead</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Good movie, Ultimately a failure</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have read at least half the comments here. I have come to the conclusion that this film failed its intent, which was to educate us Americans regarding what is really going on in the Middle East. Those of us that 'got it', already knew it. Those of us that didn't get it, and who needed to get it, the real target audience, refused to put the work into understanding this film.It's not really that difficult to grasp the concept of corporate greed in bed with judicial and executive corruption. Not that hard to see how this relationship translates into the suffering of their prey, underdeveloped countries with desirable resources. But the pacing and the quick transitions made it a little too difficult for the average moviegoer to make the connections between the various players and to easily comprehend the particular agendas and motivations of each. Like a good murder mystery all the hints were there, but the script was so tightly woven, so few words wasted, that it was necessary to pay attention to every word spoken.I didn't find the characters underdeveloped or caricatures either. They were barely characters at all and I believe this was as intended. More like the archetypes in Greek tragedy, their function was to deliver truths. A CIA operative can be just a man who happens to be a true believer, whose eyes are opened when he is victimized by those he serves and he realizes that ends are in fact not justified by the means, and never were. Or the accomplished and ambitious black lawyer who earns his father's contempt by applying his gifts to serving injustices rather than the obvious path of righting them. When the Pakistani migrant worker says he is not very religious, he is telling us something. He is telling us that Muslim terrorists aren't necessarily evil crazed subhumans motivated by religious mania, but often simply just people driven by the desperation and hopelessness of their poverty, and worry for their families to extreme acts. These are simple messages, more humanistic than political - so simple it felt like the writer was deliberately 'dumbing down' the script to accommodate my limited American attention span and unwillingness to deal with subtleties.And that is the problem. It's pointless to blame Hollywood. They are simply giving us what we ask for. Simplistic plots and and truly caricaturish heros spoon fed to us with our Happy Meals. This film was probably more generally understood in Europe, where audiences are accustomed to putting a little work into their cinema experience. The writer should probably have considered this if he really wanted to reach more people with his message.I will say, in fairness to those who didn't get it, I watched this movie on DVD with a friend, and we took a break mid-movie and talked about who was who and what was going on. There were a few places it was just a bit too fast. And at that point I was very glad that I wasn't watching it in a theater.I hope that all you who gave this movie one star because you couldn't follow it, give it another shot on DVD. All that is really needed is the pause and rewind buttons. I think you will find that is it well worth the effort.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Much</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon): "It's running out?. and ninety percent of what's left is in the Middle East. This is a fight to the death." There could not be a better introduction to the film Syriana. Although it is hyped as a 'political Hollywood film' with a 'complicated' message, Syriana is perfectly simple. The United States of America are trying by all means to keep their dominance in the Middle East. The oil reserves over there are much greater than those in for example Central Asia and Alaska. One of the means is corruption, with important consequences for the rest of the world.Gulf-prince-good-guy Nasir Al-Subaai (Alexander Siddig) explains to the Swiss energy analyst Woodman how come that his oil state is remaining so underdeveloped. "Your president calls my father. One phone call later we're stealing out of our social programs to buy overpriced airplanes." That one liner brings the story much closer to us. For one, four years ago, the Netherlands too spent almost a billion dollars in a very risky undertaking, under dubious political consequences: the American military airplane Joint Strike Fighter (JSF). Theo van Gogh got his inspiration for the film 06/05 from this, suggesting a link with the murder of Pim Fortuyn. Syriana is not made of facts and a fictional context, but the exact opposite. However, conspiracy theory lovers can enjoy both films equally.Syriana starts with the decision of the young, progressive prince Nasir Al-Subaai to grant natural gas drilling rights to a Chinese company. Obviously, the interests of the Texan energy giant Connex (having long-established business ties in the region) are severely hurt. At the same time the smaller oil company Killen has won drilling rights to coveted fields in Kazakhstan. Because of the unused production capacity, Connex starts a merger with Killen. All of a sudden, Connex-Killen is the fifth biggest oil company in the world. However, the historical merger is far from transparent. A white-shoe (conservative, Republican) law firm is brought in to prevent accusations of bribery and breaking of anti trust laws. They succeed. High ranking Killen manager Nelson is happy: "Corruption is why we win. ? Corruption is our protection." Much is happening in Syriana, at many locations. There is a way different story line of veteran CIA agent Bob Barnes (George Clooney) on a mission in Tehran as the assassin of two arms dealers. Painfully he discovers that 'his' CIA betrayed him. For years, he has been lied to, while the true reasons for his missions were never revealed. He is tortured, rescued just in time by a Hezbollah imam and finally degraded. Later on, he tries to prevent a murder attempt on prince Nasir.Much is happening at the same time too. In this perspective, Syriana is complicated. The ending is familiar. Sacked Pakistani workers hit a Connex-Killen in a suicide attack, pretty much like the USS Cole bombing in 2000. The Pakistani made use of the shaped-charge explosives that Bob Barnes has lost in Iran. All story lines come together again.Dirty and complicated. That is the reality of oil business, according to Syriana. United States expert Frank Verhagen as well as Middle East expert Paul Aarts agree on that too. Syriana is already more complex than the average Hollywood film. But the reality in the region would be several times worse. The choice to introduce a Chinese oil company in the script is typically 'Hollywood', on the other hand. Verhagen: "Yes, for about five years now, China is hot. There's not much sex in this movie - probably 'China' had to make up for it." Syriana does not provide answers, say director and actors. True. But one thing is sure after watching Syriana: in ten years time, the 'Connex-Killens' will still dominate.Is Hollywood getting more political again? So it seems. Well, George Clooney certainly is, as his roles in the recent films Good Night, and Good Luck (about the witch hunt on communists by McCarthy in the 1950s) and Syriana suggest. "Syriana is not attacking Bush and his administration. It is attacking a system that survived for sixty, seventy years now, with oil as its core", says Clooney. In another interview he was proud about Bush criticising him. Already in the first years after September 11th 2001, actors and artists were mercilessly divided into good (patriotic) and bad (not patriotic) at Celiberal.com. Clooney has never been outside Whine Rack, with Johnny Depp, Madonna and others. The Righties are for example John Travolta and (unsurprisingly) Arnold Schwarzenegger.Maybe it is nothing but a change of subject and style. Marlon Brando refused to accept his Academy Award in 1973. He was protesting against the way Hollywood pictured native Americans at that time and sent Littlefeather in his place. But in order to be an 'engaged' actor nowadays, one must be tough - against Bush, or against the terrorists.Please visit www.jasperlaros.com</fullReview>

		<date>2006-05-03</date>
		<username>kdeterra</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>An extraordinary and realistic view on what the world is becoming...and has already become.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana is a blisteringly, powerful film about the degree to which governments and corporate entities place on the ambition to control the world's oil supply above the well being of their citizens and employees. In this game, there are only bad guys, and what separates the villains from the protagonists is not a question of who's good and who's bad, but rather how bad each is willing to be. There is no point in trying to summarize the film as a whole but rather to summarize each plot thread individually. So maybe Syriana doesn't tell us anything new. But that doesn't mean that it is a dead subject. On the contrary, we need to be constantly reminded of these very real facts of modern life. And although it is complicated, it's not that hard to follow. Stephen Gaghan is an excellent writer, and he provides a nice summary of the film's action in its final the final, and very dramatic, scene. What emerges from this tangled puzzle is a web of corruption and self-interest, all fueled by the need for oil. In one plot thread, the men behind two soon-to-merge oil companies will stop at nothing to make the merger go through, since the new company will be one of the most powerful in the world.In another thread, the law firm representing the company proves that it's eager to cash in on the company's new economic success. Meanwhile, a power struggle between the two sons of an aging king in an unspecified Middle Eastern country (although Saudi Arabia is suggested) has attracted the attention of the American government, operating through the CIA agent Bob Barnes (George Clooney who begins to discover some very undesirable traits about his employers which leads him to be put under investigation. America has a vested interest in which of the king's sons succeeds him to the throne: It doesn't want the reform-minded eldest son, whose priorities will be building a country to benefit his own people; it wants instead the younger son, who will continue to relegate his country to a cosy spot in America's hip pocket and take its orders directly from the president of the USA. Further more, an up-and-coming oil broker (Matt Damon) faces an unimaginable family tragedy and finds redemption in his partnership with an idealistic Gulf prince who happens to be the reform minded elder son, Prince Nasir Al-Subai (Alexander Siddig) of the ageing King. And in the film's most chilling plot strand, we see how the struggle for oil feeds the radical Islam movement in the Middle East, providing young men with a feeling of brotherhood and righteousness in the face of a region they feel has turned its back on them in favour of big business and Western corruption. Syriana is tense, fast and furious. Following it can admittedly be somewhat exhausting, but if you pay very close attention to the first hour or so, as each story is introduced and the relationships between characters become clear, the second half of the movie is easier to digest.</fullReview>

It's a lot like the movie "Traffic" but about oil instead of drugs...I particularly thought the death of Bryan Woodman's (Matt Damon) son was overly-contrived, just to set up Woodman as Prince Nasir's economic adviser. That was too convenient, and I almost stopped watching the film because of that.As for the casting, Clooney is very good, as are a number of the other key players. But it seems to me that Christopher Plummer has played the "pure evil" role in about 300 other films, and Chris Cooper's "good ol' boy" act is getting very tiresome. Meanwhile, great actors like William Hurt and Jamey Sheridan were wasted in small roles.There is also surely enough that the U.S. has done in the Middle East to make a great non-fiction political thriller, rather than this fictional -- albeit plausible -- film.Still, the film manages to hold up, and the ending is bleak. Such is the direction in which our foreign policy is leading us.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Good movie but flawed ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I didn't agree with all of the premises of Syriana; nevertheless I thought it was a fine, engaging piece of film making, which showed the courage to ask hard questions that most supposedly 'topical' films don't. If I have one gripe, it's that the movie needed to work dramatically as well as polemically; for the most part it did, yet the ending undermined it. The film makers wanted a big climax but forget to make it consistent with the rest of the intricate story. The reason that Clooney's character is framed as a rogue operative is that his CIA cohorts don't want it to be suspected that they were behind Clooney's failed plot to assassinate an Arab leader. However, they then decide to assassinate the same Arab leader (Alexander Siddig) in a completely blatant and traceable way by targeting him with a satellite guided missile. Yes it sets up a taut ending: Clooney realizing Siddig is not the terrorist he'd been led to believe tries to avert the killing; but it makes no sense and for an otherwise intelligent thriller this was a let down.</fullReview>

We're introduced to a merger between a large oil company that's lost a big contract to China and a small oil company that somehow has been able to acquire rights to a large oil field that will reap the company billions. Bennett Holiday (Wright) is part of the government's Justic Department tasked with trying to determine whether the merger is legal, and most importantly, who must take the fall in order to ensure that the merger succeeds. Finally, Bryan Woodman (Damon) is an oil strategist who has become the right hand man to an oil sheik after the death of his child earns him the obligation. While oil is the central figure, it is the circle of life that it feeds that makes the movie enjoyable and important. Strong performances across the board. It wasn't that the characters were untrustworthy, but that their motivations were unclear in the first place.The most engaging performance comes from Alexander Siddig as the would-be heir to the throne of Lebanon, whose most noteworthy role prior to Syriana was as Dr Bashir on Star Trek Deep Space Nine. George Clooney has physically prepared for his role superbly by piling on the pounds and growing a beard that Santa Claus would be proud of, and to be fair to him it is refreshing to see him not playing the suave sophisticated type that is his usual role. Matt Damon though is rather one-dimensional, and Christopher Plummer phones it in. however this is probably the fault of neither actor, as in a convoluted script their characters are given very little development.I came out of the film scratching my head as to what exactly I had just seen. There is definitely a fascinating story buried somewhere under all the narrative, but to get to it probably requires a second, third and probably even fourth viewing - and to be honest, I don't think I could be bothered with that.</fullReview>

		<username>max-vernon</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A brave attempt which sacrifices entertainment to enlightenment.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is an art-house film dressed up as a political thriller. It is not easy to watch and demands intelligence, concentration and stamina from its audience. I left the cinema feeling a little disappointed, feeling that the bewildering complexity of characters and subplots had defied the editing process, that the film was too disjointed. It requires a second or third viewing. Yet it does sink into the subconscious and will leave a lasting impression on my psyche. It may become classic. Clooney plays the main protagonist, an experienced Middle East CIA field operative. Fluent in Farsi and Arabic, his knowledge is 'deep but narrow'. He becomes the suddenly awakened pawn and fallguy when a mission goes wrong. The film has a certain symmetry. It begins with Clooney assassinating CIA targets in Tehran. It ends with Clooney trying to prevent another CIA assassination. 'Decent', patriotic American agents like Clooney have become victims of a complex web of corruption and intrigue. There are no rules in this game of power, money and death. Corporate lawyers are as much 'foot soldiers' as the CIA operatives. Corruption and the charge of corruption are instruments of policy to subvert both foreign powers and also domestic competitors. Corporate bigwigs, political leaders and field agents are all potential sacrificial lambs. Knowledge is power and can be used against individuals as devastatingly as the missile which ends the film.The 'military-industrial complex' of which Eisenhower warned has become the modus operandi of the American political system. It now includes the oil companies whose activity is so vital to US energy needs. Governments cannot control oil companies but oil companies can control governments because the oil must be kept flowing at a reasonable price and profit. This end justifies any means. If the oil and gas stop flowing, it is Armageddon. Oil companies have effectively hijacked US foreign policy. All the rest is mere detail. American muscle is used against political leaders who threaten US interests. The CIA and Hezbollah have a working relationship. Iranian emigres and their US supporters are just itching to overthrow the Ayatollahs because 'the Persians are the natural allies of the USA'. The Chinese are now players in the oil stakes. Being a CIA agent in the Middle East is dangerous if you fall into the wrong hands: Clooney is tortured in a very harrowing scene which is not for the squeamish.The best and bravest part of the film is its attempt to depict a worm's eye view of poor Middle Eastern workers and to explore the motivation of suicide bombers. It follows the life of one young Pakistani who loses his oil job because of a merger, gets savagely beaten by the police of a corrupt Arab oil emirate, is befriended by a terrorist, 'indoctrinated' in a madrassa with the simple notion that Islam is a good under which religion and politics should become one, whereas the West is an evil which is poisoning modern life. His suicide attack against an oil installation is carried out with a US weapon which Clooney inadvertently allowed to fall into the 'wrong hands'. This emphasises the fact that the US weapons industry fuels the conflict. Firms that don't sell weapons don't make profits. Where the weapons end up is an impossible thing to control! Much of the dialogue is spoken in various languages of the Middle East with English subtitles. This gives the film both authenticity and also the feel of a documentary. The many characters are given short scenes in which to establish their various personae. The dialogue and acting are both superb. The 'Matt Damon family' scenes slow the film's hectic pace with the familiar and the mundane but a family tragedy echoes the capricious nature of the film's main theme. No one is in control of anything.The Matt Damon character explains how Arab oil wealth has been wasted and the needs of local people ignored. Attempts at reform in the area are usually blocked by the US. (Will the present US administration's new support for democracy in the area bear a less bitter fruit? The masses are not likely to vote for the rich elites whose corrupt and supine support of US interests have produced one of the greatest wealth gaps the world has ever witnessed.)Clooney's film emphasises this wealth gap. The opulent waste of corrupt rulers (one demolishes a magnificent palace in Marbella following a tragic accident) is contrasted with the extreme poverty of ordinary people and, especially, migrant workers. It is fitting that Clooney's other recent film, 'Good Night....' deals with the McCarthy era. 'Syriana' could not have been made then or just after 9/11. It does question the American economic and political system and the seeds which are now being harvested. It could be called 'Communist propaganda' and probably could not have been made if Communism was still perceived as the main threat to the interests of the USA. Political Islam has replaced Communism as the new perceived threat but both have a common origin: economic inequality and injustice. The USA is founded on narrow ideals of political freedom - an 18th Century pre-industrial Arcadia where everyone could have '40 acres and a cow' - Native Americans permitting, of course! It has yet to embrace the concept of 'economic democracy'. It offers 'riches or welfare' and has a Calvinistic belief in its Manifest Destiny under God. Clooney's film subverts this American self-belief. 'Syriana' is a brave film which tries to explore a complex political-economic system through drama. If it does not entirely succeed in what must be an impossible task it is not because it seeks to 'dumb down' but because it tries to tell the full complexity of the story. This is a noble and heroic project. It sacrifices entertainment to enlightenment but the subject is too serious for any other possibility.</fullReview>

Guest-workers working hard in producing oil for low wages get fired because the heir apparent Prince Nasir wants to give authorizations for producing the Arabian oil to the Chinese instead of the US-energy company Connex, which had them before. That's why Connex wants to take over the small energy company Killen, which just made a very profitable deal with oil from Kazakhstan. So the department of justice wants a lawyer's office from Washington to control this takeover. But what follows is everything else than neutral control. The attorney Bennet Holiday (Jeffrey Wright) gives as many information about the Killen's activities in Kazakhstan to the department of justice as they need to fool the public with the image of constitutional legacy without putting the Connex deal on any risks.A special character, but just one of them, is the Arabian Prince Nasir, represented by Alexander Sidding in a very charismatic way. He wants democracy and he wants his country to get rid of the economical American influences. Of course Washington cannot accept that, they'd rather like to see Nasir's younger brother getting more power. So they assign Bob Barnes from the CIA to kill Nasir. This CIA guy is played by George Clooney with impressive physical and mental charisma. Like almost all of the movie's characters also Bob Barnes is a mixture of good and bad: on the one hand he's a family father, on the other hand he's the loyal state controlled killer. Last but definitely not least there's Matt Damon, who's performing in his well known, competent way. He's playing the analyst Bryan Woodsman who gets the offer to become Prince Nasir's personal assistant, after his son died because of a very tragic accident at a celebration in honor of Prince Nasir.Syriana is a very special political thriller. The dramaturgy is complex and because of that it seems to be confusing at the first view, but it's totally logical and realistic exciting. The script is fantastic and the actors are in a brilliant shape. When you don't understand everything in the first time, go to see it once more, it's worth it!Syriana is a real cinematographic highlight!And by the way, we can finalize, that George Clooney has become one of the best in Hollywood. 		<shortDescription>one great political thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Prince Nasir Al-Subaai, first born son, is patiently waiting to take over his dying father's oil company, located in the Persian Gulf. Nasir dreams to reform his country, creating a Parliament, seeking equal rights for his people. Employing energy trading consultant Bryan Woodman, Nasir aims for the most profitable path, increasing the rate of his dream. Bryan starts to question his work, after the death of his son at a party, held at Nasir's home. The mined oil connects with long-time ties to American company Connex. Smaller oil company Killen, plans to merge with Connex, set to reap massive profits. Head of Killen, Jimmy Pope has received rights to oil fields in Kazakhstan. Connex wanting this merging just as much as Killen, able to expand their production capacity. Raising suspicion, the Justice Department investigates this merger between Connex and Killen. Attorney Bennett Holiday is hired by Connex and Killen, to keep the Justice Department happy, till the completion of the merger.Seeking the highest profits, Nasir decides to cut this connection with Connex, planning to deal with China, outbidding America. Dean Whiting, head of law firm Sloan Whiting; which Bennett works for, realises the compromising position this holds for America if Nasir deals with China. Dean attempts to make Nasir's brother Prince Meshal the predecessor; envy of fame and power, cowering easily to Dean's and Connex's demands. CIA agent Bob Barnes, is given his last undercover assignment, to assassinate Prince Nasir. When one of Banres's contacts turns against him, the assassination fails and the American Government turns their heads, using Banres as a scapegoat, to cover their motivations.Screen writer Stephen Gaghan has ventured to uncover the world of corruption on petroleum, like his script for Traffic, uncovering the world of drugs. Using multiple characters and complex story lines, (which is confusing at first), Gaghan shows the political agendas from every side; America, Arabia, the workers and the people pulling the strings from behind the scenes. There has been so much smoke and mirrors surrounding the debate of control over the worlds most profitable resource and who reins control. Based on Robert Baer's book 'See No Evil', Gagher has cuts straight to the core of the situation, revealing the curtain on what is really happening. Gaghan's direction takes a slant towards documentary style; camera shaking between characters and scenes, conjures a realistic manner, you feel that your right in there with these people.While the political side of Syriana can confuse and fly off on a tangent, grounding it are the character's dilemmas caught in the web of this corrupt game; humanizing what could have been a dry political film. Each character fights for their best interest, many taking extreme measures to realise them. While there's corruption in the mild east, the government has control of the regulation, which many profit from and aim to keep this from changing.Putting on a lot of weight for the role, George Clooney brings a such a strong performance. Matt Damon seems misplaced as Bryan, you don't see a lot of grief for a man who has just lost his son. Jeffrey Wright also brings a strong performance, though just falls behind Clooney. Stand out is Alexander Siddig as Nasir, showing such pain and determination for his dream of a free country. In their supporting roles, Chris Cooper, Amanda Peet and Christopher Plummer are all great.While the story and plot of Syriana may be contrived and hard to follow, the core of this film is the real pay off. The story is just a vehicle to pass the message on, and what an eye opening message it is, finally blowing the top off this corporation corruption.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Holding up the mirror to show the age and body of the time his form and pressure</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Hamlet summed it up rather well when he talked about the purpose of playing, "whose end, both at the first and now, was and is, to hold, as 'twere, the mirror up to nature; to show virtue her own image, scorn her own image, and the very age and body of the time his form and pressure" Syriana holds up the mirror to the very age and body of American culture and finds much worthy of scorn. The only virtue we see reflected here is that of a mid-eastern emir-in-waiting (Alexander Siddig) who seeks to promote the welfare of all of the subjects he is intended to rule. Of course such notions, that endanger the salary hikes of American company directors, mean that he has to be eliminated. And if good old-fashioned bribery and corruption are not going to attain that purpose, then high tech, government operated killing machines can be pressed into service. The only other virtuous party (read virtue as honour devoid of self interest) is Hezbolah. They are depicted as continuing the traditions of chivalry their ancestors taught to the barbarian European crusaders in the middle ages. This is revolutionary stuff. Think about it. George Clooney plays a government employee who kills civilians (and emirs in waiting) and sells weapons of mass destruction. Think mirror ? think Al Quaida attack on an American ship in port. All his working life he has been used by and he probably never knew what for. If it was for the betterment of his family, his son has him sussed as a liar not worth spending any time with. And when he seeks to avert the evil that is about to take please he is impotent. Matt Damon plays an intelligent and likable consultant, whose employer will make millions from reports that sprout that "consultant speak" like "optimising the outcomes by strategic placement of emerging opportunities." Granted, what Damon's character says seems to make sense, a matter that does not go unnoticed by the emir-in-waiting, whose beliefs and ideals are mirrored in the advice being offered. But it all ends in Damon's character crawling from the wreckage and slinking back home to a child who has not yet picked up on his mother's acceptance of the idea of 'life without dad'. Is this a call for return to the policies of pre-World War Two isolationism? And then there are the government and business company men and women whose actions reflect the line, "Corruption is our protection. It's what keeps us safe and warm. We have laws about it precisely so we can get away with it. Corruption is how we win." And to keep it all in balance, let's not overlook the unsavoury depiction of the recruiter of suicide bombers, or his less than inspiring victim, who seems to be more concerned about employment opportunities than with the grand scheme of fighting against the evils perpetrated by latter day crusaders. The morning after seeing this film, I heard a programme from Colorado's excellent Alternative Radio organization, in which Naom Chomsky expressed with rather more intellectual precision the ideas so stylishly portrayed by Stephen Gaghan's writing and direction. Gaghan's "Traffic" script used a similar approach. Introduce the viewer to the characters in chance encounters, just as would happen in real life. Gaghan turns his back on that appallingly hackneyed, first-half-hour-of-the movie character development parodied so mercilessly by Zucker, Zucker and Abraham's "Flying High". Having big name, charismatic actors alleviates any real problem for the viewer in navigating through the narrative. Like life, this is haphazard. It develops in fits and starts, often with no immediately apparent rhyme or reason. I am tempted to suggest that there must be hope for any culture that can hold up the mirror to its values in the way Syriana does. But then I am forced to admit that America re-elected a president who reflects the interests so scorned by this film, even after the Academy gave the nod to Michael Moore's cinematic antics.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Crowded, confused, convincing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a well made thriller ? Tom Clancy with something to say ? with a multi-track plot and fine performances from many of the huge (over 70) speaking cast. The ending, like "Arlington Road", is rather melancholy. The confusion caused by inter-cutting between the different plot strands and the many characters does resolve itself in the end but it also blunts the message. The assassination scenario and the terrorist scenario have only an incidental connection (the same Gulf state is involved) and there is no dramatic confrontation between terrorist and victim. Stephen Gaghan the director and writer, wrote "Traffic", a complicated but mostly successful expose of the drug trade and he has adopted the same crowded, complicated approach here. There are some nice set pieces eg Tim Blake-Nelson's Gordon Gecko-like oil company lobbyist's spirited defence of corruption ("it keeps us safe and warm"), Christopher Plummer's put-down of the not over-bright younger Arab prince, and Matt Damon's arrogant but regrettably correct analysis of the prospects of desert society after their oil runs out. There is only one significant female role (Amanda Peet as Mrs Damon) - oil is a men's business.It's not really fair to criticize a thriller on the grounds of historical inaccuracy ? it is enough that it be engrossing enough to suspend our disbelief, and this film certainly is. Yet, having recently in the line of duty plowed through a weighty tome on relations between the US government and the oil industry over the last 80 years, I am aware that the oil industry does not always get its way with the government, and vice versa. Also, it is true that the CIA was involved in assassination attempts on foreign political figures (Castro from Cuba and Lummumba from the Congo for example) in the 1950s and 1960s, as a former director put it "with remarkable lack of success though not for want of trying." All this came out in US Senate Committee hearings in 1976 (the Church Committee). But since Gerald Ford was president assassination has ceased to be government policy, mainly because it was seen as ineffective and unpredictable, even with the high tech approach shown in the film which is nearly thwarted by a flock of sheep. The background to all this is set out in another weighty tome "The Agency" by John Ranelagh (1986), a book the Israeli government obviously hasn't read.George Clooney's performance as Bob the washed-up CIA agent is truly wonderful ? I loved the bit where he wanders nonchalantly past the Peugeot (containing two arms dealers) he has just blown up ("who me?"). He's got the Oscar as far as I am concerned. Of the rest, Alexander Siddig as Nasir the reformist prince and Matt Damon as Bryan the energy analyst stood out, the first for his intensity and the second for playing against type. Christopher Plummer always makes a great villain and does so here ? he has the best heartless grin in the business.The editing is pretty well perfect, which is absolutely crucial in a movie with as much pace and action as this one. I'm surprised Tim Squyres was not nominated for an Oscar. Although there is a big bang in the film it is left to our imaginations ? the final motif is the anti-climactic yet entirely appropriate one of getting home after a hard day at the office.There will no doubt come a day when we do not need to fight wars over oil, but don't hold your breath. Personally, I am looking forward to the day Canada is annexed by the US to secure its access to the second largest oil reserves in the world, the Athabasca tar sands. I've always thought the Canadians too smug by half because they aren't Americans. Prince Nasir is blowed if he can tell the difference. But then Bob Barnes isn't really a Canadian.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I'm disappointed this movie was not nominated for Best Picture. For those who seem confused about what the point of this movie is, read on. It's hard to fathom a world where things do not appear as black and white, but this is the world we live in. Our current administration has used the tragic events of 9/11 to paint an "us against them" mentality that has polarized our position away from the rest of the world and facilitated Americans to turn a blind eye to what's really going on. The fact of the matter is, our enemies are not a group of psychotically deranged terrorists, hell-bent on killing every man woman and child, they are equally politically motivated as we are. They resort to such abhorrent measures like suicide bombings and hostage beheadings because those are the only means available to them. Furthermore, consistent with their own environment, they do not place the same value on human life that we do and consequently they do not fear death the way we do. Anyway. . . Syrianna strikes at the center of this dichotomy of cultures by showing that the plight in the parts of the world that harbor terrorists is connected with our own country's exploits and opportunism. I agree that globalization is good, but the point of the movie is that our own actions that may benefit all Americans facially do have long term consequences that are only foreseeable to those who have the power to do anything about it yet don't care because of their personal incentives to let someone else worry about it while they profit. It would be no understatement to say that members of our government are part of this effort, as demonstrated in the movie. Bottom line is we all have to be more cognizant of the actions our country takes around the world. These international, foreign actions are how the world judges us; not Mom and Pop operating their convenient store in Anytown USA. It is of the essence that people hold our government accountable, only through transparency can we assure credibility. Currently our government goes to great lengths only to present an illusion of doing the right thing without doing the right thing at all. I am not some flaming liberal, I just have a very firm grip on reality. So, if you didn't "get" the movie, watch it again, and think about how important it is that everything is more than only tenuously connected.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Ninety minutes' worth of story in two hours of film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went into this film really wanting to like it. I'd heard great things, and I was interested to see how the film would deal with the very complex topic of politics and oil in the middle-east. I walked out very disappointed.The story is great. There are enough twists and turns and there's enough emotion involved to really propel the story forward. The direction, however, hinders that forward motion. Instead of concentrating on the narrative drive, the film seems more interested in taking a series of detours through the details of the characters' lives. It slows down the momentum of what could've been a great thriller/conspiracy tale. Instead of wondering what was going to happen next, I found myself guessing which character would be the next to preach about US foreign policy, wondering if the actors found this scene a challenge to play, and trying to determine if this dialog would go on long enough that I could get some more candy from the concession stand and be back before the next real plot point.The cinematography, however, did help keep me awake- fingernails on a chalkboard often have that effect. I'm sure the director was thinking, "Let's give the movie a realistic, documentary-type feel! It'll add some immediacy to the whole thing." Heaven knows we need some immediacy with the meandering pace of the film. But this misguided notion led the filmmakers to shoot the entire movie with hand-held cameras, which detracts from the shots, distracts from the action, and at times even disorients the viewer.These two problems, though they did, in fact, ruin the movie for me, don't completely destroy it. If you can stave off drowsiness and motion sickness, the film still has plenty to offer. All of the actors are quite good in their roles. The plot, though it unravels slowly, is fairly compelling, and the film makes its points about foreign policy and greed and all fairly well. The script is strong, the emotional impact is there, and (other than the camera-work) the movie is well-made. It's just boring.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>2005 has been a blockbuster year for George Clooney, who won heady praise for his writer/director/producer role on "Good Night, and Good Luck," and for his performance as CIA Agent Bob Barnes in "Syriana," a collaboration with Stephen Gaghan (who scripted the similar "Traffic"). Many of the exact details of the international syndicate's actions remain undefined, but their general aim is clear, and motives are easily inferred.While Clooney is getting most of the 'buzz' this awards season, Alexander Siddig's excellent turn as Prince Nasir (his second character of that name this year) is perhaps even better. Nasir is an idealized reformist character, but Siddig makes him believable, and you truly want him to succeed, even as it seems clear that he won't. It's interesting to note the differences between this and Clooney's other political film; GNaGD argued that good men, like Edward R. Murrow, could topple villains like McCarthy if they stuck to their principles; "Syriana"'s ultimate message is that we're probably screwed, regardless of what we try to do, because the problems of the world are beyond anyone's ability to solve. Depressing, but almost sadly realistic.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Bob Barnes: loyal CIA operative to the end (an argument)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Disclaimer: Nobody I have talked to agrees with me.My argument is that Agent Bob Barnes deliberately halts Prince Nasir's caravan in order to make it an easier target for the U.S. missile, and in so doing, end his life having served his country and proved his loyalty.The story of a CIA operative who, after twenty years of faithful service, suddenly decides to swap sides, simply doesn't wash, and Gaghan is far too clever a screenwriter to allow such a cliché. Barnes could not have possibly prevented the assassination by doing what he did, and he would have known it. Fuirthermore, when Bob returns home after being tortured, he never asks why he was tortured or even who was behind it. He assumes he already knows the answer: Prince Nasir.Instead he wants to know why he is "being investigated." It becomes his mantra, in fact, and he is never given a straight answer. After years of never questioning orders, Bob becomes desperate to clear his good standing with the organization he has been faithful to his entire life, even at the cost of his own life.His motivations include revenge, of course, and this is the key to the final moment between him and the prince. Had the prince been in any way involved with Mussawi, he would have immediately recognized Bob as the man who tried to have him assassinated in Beirut. But no, he only recognizes him as the Canadian he met in the elevator.In this scenario, Bob's final thought before the missile hits would be, "He's innocent. Oh my God, I'm killing the wrong man."Take it or leave it, the script's ambiguities certainly leave room for such an interpretation, and I can only conclude that this is deliberate. After all, it ties in quite nicely with one of the film's primary themes:Never assume you know who's working for who.</fullReview>

		<username>dunmore_ego</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Oil Is Not Well.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If "oily Arab" was once an insult referring to a Middle Easterner's complexion, nowadays it should truly be considered the highest compliment, pertaining to certain Arabs (via birthright and political wolfing), controlling the fortunes of the planet Earth via oil.If there is an overarching message to this movie's madness, it is that everyone else on Earth, in their methods to obtain that oil, displays a savagery no different than the sociopathic desert-dwellers in *The Road Warrior* who would sacrifice their lives, loved ones and integrity to get their hands on "the precious juice". (To wit: the American military is shown identifying a vehicle from an orbiting satellite and blowing it up with pinpoint accuracy, in a government-sanctioned murder, to retain a corporate stranglehold. Does no one else find it extremely disturbing that not only do they have the capability and impunity to do this, but that our knowledge of this crime in no way brings those culpable closer to punishment?) Whereas the *Road Warrior* wastrels targeted small supplies of gasoline for the short-term resources they yielded, now we deal in whole nations of subterranean crude, corporate decimation of livelihoods and premeditated killings the dialect of political *coups* that guarantees the black gold flows into the pockets of those with ? as in *The Road Warrior* - the grandest killing technology. Blink once ? and the plot of *Syriana* will tear by you like a bullet-train. But the plot is a McGuffin. (I imagine the Real World's corporate collusions work in much the same way. Left hands not only do not know what Right hands are doing, sometimes Left cuts off Right to spite the Torso.) Inspired by Robert Baer's book, "See No Evil: The True Story of a Ground Soldier in the CIA's War on Terrorism", Director Stephen Gaghan uses the neck-snapping plot line ? crash-cutting across numerous scenarios that play out very separately, marginally inter-relating - to illustrate how oil machinations on a global level affect lives on a personal level.George Clooney - unrecognizable beneath hermit-friendly facial hair, a cultivated paunch and an absence of comedic head-waggling - is Bob Barnes, a government contract killer miles above your average mafia hit-man, who has never cared to question the reasons or motives behind his job ? until now ? when a hit he is assigned goes awry and his employers try to discredit and discard him, inspiring in him a cause for living - or dying, whichever comes first. (A torture scene involving Clooney rivals the level of discomfort ? for the audience ? as that of Dustin Hoffman's "Is it safe?" scene from *Marathon Man*.)Matt Damon (playing dead straight as Financial Analyst Bryan Woodman) lands a hundred-mil contract with Prince Nasir (played with grounded sympathy by Alexander Siddig) under the most inauspicious of circumstances: as recompense for the accidental death of his young son in the Prince's palace pool. Jeffrey Wright (as lawyer Bennett Holiday) is assigned to forage for evidence of corruption in an oil-related corporate merger. As obvious a joke as this may seem - the word "corporate" these days being tantamount to "corruption" - the reality is darker than Bennett or the audience can fathom: as a shareholder accounts to Bennett (paraphrasing his monologue): "Corruption isn't just a way of life ? Corruption is what makes life in the First World possible!"William Hurt, fast becoming the Christopher Walken of cameos, here supplies a Deep Throat presence for Barnes.Intersticed between the clam-chowder-thick political meandering, a human resonance is defined in subplots involving father-son relationships with each of the main characters, and how the Oil trade decimates those relationships; particular poignancy in the motivation behind young, disillusioned Muslim, Wasim (Mazhar Munir), jobless due to the corporate merger, and inured to his father's empty promises of a better life, latching onto a holy reason for living (or dying, whichever comes first). As he relates in a recorded video testament, "Let it be known I died pure in spirit."As it happens, Barnes also finds the same peace in the climactic finale, the movie wrapping with reconciliation for many of the characters. After the challenging, disjointed plot line refusing to infantilize its audience with pat expositions disguised as character dialogue, the ending itself became too pat. The tragic reality is that this unholy plotting and sanctioned high-level murder goes on at all, under the veneer of reciprocal altruism, religiosity and supposedly intelligent bureaucracy. And it continues even as you read this, unresolved, unceasing. A two-hour movie cannot even scratch the surface? We ultimately reach a quandary of ideology: if both sides (American and Middle Eastern governments) are prepared to forgo their religious and political beliefs to conspire in assassinations that eliminate business obstacles, then why exactly are they on opposing sides? Because both sides somehow idiotically believe that in the long run they may somehow tilt the balance of power in their favor. How they would manage to achieve that in a closed supply-and-demand system is anyone's guess?And we thought only mohawked, leather-chapped, chain-wielding, ambiguously-gay road warriors behaved with such imbecility.(Movie Maniacs, visit: www.poffysmoviemania.com)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>eastbergholt2002</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Clever and thought provoking</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana is an attempt to explain the relationship between the U.S. and the oil-rich Arab countries. The movie presents a world where U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East is mainly about keeping the oil flowing. Syriana is a fictional state, modeled probably on Saudi Arabia, where the CIA and the large oil companies have an interest in preserving the status quo. Syriana is about to get a new leader (Alexander Siddig) who has been educated in the West (Oxford, Georgetown) and wants to end his country's subservience. The U.S. intervenes and uses its influence to replace Siddiq with his younger pro-Western brother. The movie is written and directed by Steven Gaghan who adapted the movie Traffic from the British mini-series. It adopts a similar quasi-documentary style with several competing and inter-related story lines. George Clooney plays a hard-bitten CIA operative who has an epiphany and wants to do the right thing. Matt Damon is a brain for hire who helps and advises the trouble-making prince (Siddig). Jeffrey Wright plays a lawyer who faces a moral dilemma as he confronts corruption during the merger of two large U.S. oil companies active in Syriana. Mazhar Munir is a Pakistani worker who falls prey to the recruiting efforts of a militant Islamic cleric, and is told he will go to paradise if he becomes a suicide bomber. The movie is complicated and you need your wits about you to follow what's going on. The message of the story is that U.S. energy companies,law firms and government are in collusion. The movie implies that Arab leaders are corrupt and installing puppet regimes is likely to turn encourage anti-Americanism and militant Islam. The movie shows the nasty ark secret things that are done in our name to keep us in the style to which we have become accustomed. However, as long as the U.S. remains addicted to oil we are probably stuck with the current policies and the movie doesn't present any plausible alternatives.</fullReview>

He draws on that experience and while not over doing it, does it well. He plays a role as a CIA agent in the Middle East who is going through a change of life, questioning himself, his motives and his involvement with his own country and what he has seen it become. While his is a strong and important role, he is not the main character.All characters play equal and equally important parts in this film. This is hard to do without slighting anyone but Clooney does it masterfully. It is truly a strong work but shy of calling it a work of art. It is brutal, it is honest and is based on events we all see everyday in the news.His friend and working actor Matt Damon plays an important role not unlike his other characters Clooney has had him play previously. This one is much more serious however.This story centers on a small oil company gaining the rights to an oil kingdom's fields when there is no way it could have pulled it off. It had help and from the beginning merges with another oil company to keep its end of the bargain. The deal is predicated on the simple decision the kingdom has made to sell much of what it has to China. China, having an economy growing at a rate faster than any other in the world. It will grow faster only if it gets more oil.Eerily in recent weeks China and India (in real life) signed a deal with British Petroleum to take over oil fields in Syria, thus providing those two hugely consuming nations key access to middle eastern oil. Not likely but it is extremely interesting on the timing.Getting back to Syriana, make no mistake about it, this is a politically charged film with an agenda. The agenda is defensible certainly and I see it as an important film for the new century. The side story of a young Pakistani man working in the oil fields losing his job (because of the China deal) and being led onward by Moslem extremists is frightening in itself. The real life drama being played out in Syriana is most moving and very disturbing.I recommend this film to anyone and everyone. 		<date>2005-12-29</date>
		<username>opiyo (opiyo@stellarpictures.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>just because there's hardly room for argument, doesn't mean its complicated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Once in a while we see a film that entertains and stimulates thought. Not necessarily answering any questions, but perhaps suggesting that there are questions among us that need to be asked. This is Syriana, a film by the creators of the Academy Award winning drama, Traffic (Steven Gaghan and Steven Soderbergh). The film is adapted from "See no Evil", a novel written by former CIA agent, Robert Baer. Syriana reels audiences in through multiple story lines that are convincing and relative to our current social crisis. And for those who would rather believe there is no crisis, the film can present an alternative perspective through it's attempt to express how the arrogance of world powers like the US, can effect people in less developed societies. Syriana is set in an oil-producing country off the Gulf, where its prince prepares to succeed his ailing father. Envisioning his country further developing and moving towards complete independence, the Prince abandons US interest in his country's oil and pursues a higher offering from the Chinese. Connex, a Texas energy plant subsequently looses oil-drilling rights in that region. In efforts to preserve productivity, Connex sets out to merge with Killen, a smaller Texas oil company. A speculative US justice department then sends in a major law firm to investigate the legalities behind the business deal.Bennett Holiday (Jeffrey Wright) enters as lawyer on the case. His boss, Dean Whiting (Christopher Plummer), head of the firm, is adamant on ceasing the Prince's mission with the Chinese. Whiting begins to convince the Prince's sick father to choose the youngest and less mature of the sons to succeed as ruler. Blind to his father and youngest brother's interactions with the US, the Prince continues to prepare to be ruler and throws a party at his estate. At the party, a tragedy occurs where a young boy accidentally dies. The boy happened to be the son of Energy analyst Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon). The Prince empathetically offers Bryan an astronomical business deal and builds a relationship with him that clarifies where he wants to take his country economically as Prince and future ruler. However, the pact the Prince made with the Chinese consequently terminated the jobs of numerous laborers that bussed daily to the secluded desert energy fields for work.This leaves Pakistani workers like, Wasim (Mazhar Munir) and his father, Saleem Ahmed Kahn (Shahid Ahmed), hopeless. Soon Wasim's anger would elevate to find him in a madrassa (an Islamic school for Muslims, just as parochial schools for Catholics) where he experiences support from those with similar realities. Once there, they are in the cunning hands of a dangerous Egyptian recruiter bearing a massive weapon he surreptitiously received during an indirect transaction involving veteran CIA agent Bob Barnes (George Clooney). Barnes floats through the story constantly on assignment, nearing retirement, and ignorant towards the true motives of the US government, nevertheless, he takes strong pride in serving his country.Syriana illuminates the loom of capitalism, and how it weaves our realities of dependency into something that can leave each of us as both oppressor and sufferer in our social dilemmas. To the average person who pays the least bit of attention to current events while carrying the most basic understanding of history, the film offers nothing new. However, there is a pleasure we receive from just experiencing how things work. In that respect, this motion picture becomes entertaining in its ability to express the intricacies of economics, ethics, and people in a globalized society. Syriana portrays a world where everything is connected and while feeding on ignorance, corruption makes the world go round, leaving viewers with the question: Can my beloved government only be getting better at getting worse?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>No Bullseye, but hits the board</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The 7 of 10 rating is on the mark. This is a good movie, but it is not all that it could be or maybe should be. It weaves an intricate web that for most will take repeat viewing or pre-viewing prep to really get it all. In that sense you are left to compare your version of the puzzle with those of your viewing mates. That is something I liked about this movie. It really makes you think, but it requires that you pay attention and not let the little points pass you by or you will be without the needed pieces. What I did not like is although the movie is complex, it is complicated by thin character development because you can't stay with one long enough to feel them out. We are left to read between the lines if you can remember which lines to read between. And while you are looking for the unifying theme (other than oil) you get entangled in the big conspiracy. But there seems to be a distinct flow in the movie logic - Greed begets corruption. Corruption begets compromise. Compromise begets betrayal. Betrayal begets hopelessness. Hopelessness begets martyrdom/terrorism, take your pick. In general it makes the world at large seem very bleak. Yet, while nobility does get smart-bombed, Hezzbullah has an honor code or political savvy, take your pick, all is not lost?If you like cerebral and suspenseful thrillers, you'll like this movie. But to remind you (or show you) of what they were trying to achieve, take another peek at Traffic.</fullReview>

If you don't watch the news and are not up on middle east politics, you might find it confusing as the subtleties will be lost on you.But what about as a film itself? Context aside I think the Gaghan did a pretty good job with the medium and the overall production of a very ambitious 2hr film. In many ways, I think this would have been a better 6hr mini series (much like the original Traffik -http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096716/) but he does do a good job with the big screen. There is certainly enough material for it and would have given him more of a chance to flesh out the fascinating back stories that he just so much wanted to tell-- in some cases too much so. The story of the dead child for example perhaps I would have cut in order to focus more on the principle characters. Despite these minor issues, a very engrossing film, I will for sure rent to watch again when it comes out on DVD-- hopefully with another hour of material that was cut from the theatrical release.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>More moving parts than a truck</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's impossible in this space to lay out the plot for "Syriana," but it is possible to say why this film works so well. Like "Traffic," this film is not so much a single story as a series of interlocking and overlaid stories, all of them revolving around oil and the places where it comes from. And like "Traffic," this film works so well because it's so complex. There are no truly good guys, and many of the bad guys demonstrate at least some redeeming qualities. (There are some exceptions.) And there are no easy answers to any of the many problems raised by this film, so the filmmakers don't offer any. They just force you to think. That process alone is worth the price of admission.</fullReview>

		<date>2007-08-23</date>
		<username>qqppaallzzmm</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Insightful and terrifying</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana delves into the inner workings of the oil industry and sets out to illustrate its impact on every level of society.The film consists of many stories that develop throughout the movie and ultimately come together in the end. A young, ambitious economist (Matt Damon) is eager to assist Prince Nasir in his efforts to revolutionize his country, whilst a veteran CIA operative (George Clooney) becomes entangled in a web of conspiracy over a foiled plot to assassinate an Arab Prince. Meanwhile, on the other side of the world, a suspicious merger between two oil companies has aroused much controversy and a young optimistic lawyer is recruited to investigate. Amidst all of this, a young Pakistani oil worker is led into a path of hatred and coerced into sacrificing himself.Syriana looks at how the world is connected through the oil business. At its core, it attempts to illustrate the effect that a tradable substance of value, such as oil, has on society. In a world where human life and social responsibility come second to economic security and prosperity, oil is at the forefront of decision making in many elements of society, and Syriana attempts to convey this message through a series of interconnecting stories focusing around one period of time and influenced by one important commodity, oil. Whilst this concept of film making is by no means a 'novel' approach, ("go" and "babel" spring to mind), Gaghan does a superb performance of bringing the multiple story lines together. The film requires undivided attention to fully appreciate the connections between the stories, however viewers are rewarded for the efforts as the links unravel towards the dramatic climax. The film illustrates the profound differences between cultures as men on one side of the world negotiate billion dollar mergers whilst, on the other side of the world, hundreds of employees are left without work and struggle to find meaning in their lives. The performances throughout the movie are superb with Mazhar Munir brilliantly portraying the thousands of workers that are displaced as a result of the greed within the oil industry. An unshaven George Clooney delivers a performance unlike any role he's played before as the veteran CIA agent that is struggling to unravel a web of conspiracy and coverups surrounding him.The music throughout the film is minimal with a simple piano piece repeated throughout the picture. The film begins and ends in a similar fashion as the pace of the movie slows down completely from the roller-coaster ride that we witness throughout most of the picture. Large desert shots work effectively at both the beginning and end of the film to demonstrate both the lack of emotion that the oil companies have and the feeling of emptiness that the thousands of workers that are displaced by the relentless efforts of these companies to achieve greater profits.Syriana is both an insightful look at the profit-driven oil companies and a terrifying look at the impact of multinational billion dollar companies on every level of society. The film has been brilliantly put together and director Stephen Gaghan delivers 100% in a genre of film that he's all too familiar with. However, the film is slightly let down by an overly complex story line, and many viewers will leave feeling dissatisfied and confused.Its unfortunate that more films like Syriana aren't able to be produced. A must see!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Robert J. Maxwell (rmax304823@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>The illusion of due diligence.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are a lot of things to admire about this film. The location shooting may not be scenic but it's instructive. The goat-herding bedouin seem organic to the tawny and treeless landscape. The bloated oil tanks and the black empty ribbons of highway seem imposed on it.The acting is pretty good. I couldn't find a flaw in the casting. The score is suspenseful without being bombastic. There is a horrific scene of torture and the anticipation of death, involving the most realistic beating I've ever seen on the screen. It doesn't last long, and it doesn't have to. It recalls the cutting off of the captive cop's ear in "Reservoir Dogs," only the director here doesn't seem to take the same kind of glee in the depiction of suffering. The theme is relevant and ambitious -- oil corrupts, and absolute oil corrupts absolutely.The script, though, put me to sleep the first time I tried to watch the movie. It takes a while to sort the characters and their motives out. Novels, including the one this story is based on, can afford complicated multiple plots and subplots. And to be honest, more often than not "major motion pictures" made from novels tend to prune out all the obfuscations that might confuse an eleven-year-old mind. Usually the result is good guys vs. bad guys with a lot of gunfire and explosions in slow motion. Oh, and a nude babe lurking somewhere in the background for when the action slows down.The problem with "Syriana" is the opposite. The subplots are woven together in a way that's not easy to follow, and the motives of the characters are more hinted at except in a few cases of flagrant finger pointing. It isn't that a successful movie can't be made out of diverse points of view centering on an important issue. "Traffic" did it quite well.If there are identifiable "bad guys", they're American oil companies, the law firms that represent them, and the corrupt Emirs in the oil-rich Middle East who sell out to them for personal favors. There's another murderous organizational entity involved too. SOMEBODY blows up the reformist Arab prince and the American who is trying to save him. And the organization is an American one with access to spy satellites and guided missiles. I just can't figure out which organization it is. The American Civil Liberties Union? The Boy Scouts? The Little Sisters of the Poor? It might have made a good mini-series. Or it might have made two or three compact and cogent features. As it is, though, things are so squashed together that we can't really get a good handle on all of it. I don't, for instance, have any idea of what Matt Damon's character's motives might be. Is he an idealist? Or is he, as his wife claims, parlaying the death of his six-year-old into a position of influence. Both? That would be a nice touch, but then we'd need to know a little more about how he handles it.Bonus point for a tense script about conflict in the Middle East in which not a single shot is fired.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The world of oil comes full circle</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana ****. Stephan Gaghan (Traffic) directs this take off of a book by Robert Baer. The movie tells a story about oil, and those things which are related to oil. From CIA assassinations, to corporate mergers, to corruption, to Middle Eastern Kingdoms, to suicide bombers, 'Syriana'shows the circle of life which has been created because of this black gold we call oil.There are multiple story lines here that are all connected in some way. George Clooney plays Bob Barnes, a seasoned CIA veteran in the Middle East. Matt Damon plays an American sent to propose a large deal for oil with a royal family. That same Royal family is being pressured by the US to make the younger, weaker brother heir to the throne so that they can easier exploit the oil reserves in the country. The older, stronger brother dreams of making his country stable and independent with a strong economy that will be no longer squandered. A deal between Damon's character's business and the family goes down, but only because of an unfortunate death due to a freak accident. Back in America, Bennett Holiday (Jeffrey Wright) attempts to get to the bottom of a corruption scandal in the oil companies which are seeking the rights to the Middle Eastern oil. Two young men take to the cause of suicide bombing and we are given reasons why, and what they are thinking to do such a thing.I could sit here for quite some time trying to intertwine and explain all the story lines in 'Syriana,' but it can all really be summed up by saying that it is a story about the effects of the oil business. The story told is jumbled, and sometimes incoherent, but works wonderfully. Life is jumbled and complicated, and even more so in such environments as portrayed here. It only fits that it be difficult. Another reason why the film works so well just as it is, is because of the performances here. Not only are the leads wonderful, but the smaller characters are fantastic as well. Everybody does their job to perfection here, and the payoff is gold. Everyone is their character, not someone playing that character. It gives a sense of realism to the film that is rarely found these days in most blockbuster films. Clooney, Damon and company do some of their best work. William Hurt, Chris Cooper, and Christopher Plummer are also very good here, and they make up some of those actors with smaller parts who came out and gave it their all. Particularly good, as always, is Tim Blake Nelson. He plays a corrupt business man who gives one of the most passionate speeches in defense of corruption you will ever see.'Syriana' has been accused of being boring and leftist among other things. I, for one, was never bored and I was captivated the whole way through. Is the film a bit to the left? I don't know, but everything we've learned about the corruption in big business, such as the oil business, is put on display here in pretty realistic fashion. The story is difficult to understand at all times, but just as in real life, we are not always meant to understand everything we see, but we are obliged to follow it and see it through. This is one of the best films of the year, and it should be seen more than once to grasp it a little better. If you don't like it at first, give it a second shot. A film this good deserves it.10/10</fullReview>

		<username>0rganism</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>a complex, intricate, tightly-packed movie with an important message</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you like a movie that doesn't talk down to the audience and isn't afraid to push forward with touchy issues, this is going to be your cup of tea. However, viewers beware: the first hour is going to require some careful attention to seemingly unimportant details, and whatever one misses early-on is going to compromise overall comprehension of the plot later in the movie. That is simultaneously the mechanism for Syriana's greatest cinematic achievement and the deepest failing of the film. The earlier one figures out who the players are and what's motivating them, the more engrossing the storyline will be as it unfolds.Each scene is meticulously presented and follows reasonably from the preceding material, but many of the characters and themes are introduced exactly once. From then on, you're on your own, and if you missed something because you were reaching for the popcorn, well, you're going to be leaving the theater with some unanswered questions. This potential difficulty is exacerbated by the rapid-fire context switches that occur, which can zoom to the opposite side of the planet with a completely different set of characters operating on events in a way which may seem, at most, tangentially connected to the original topic.To understand the intricacies of the plot, one must be prepared to discard the usual notions of spoon-fed character development through repetition, and accept the job of piecing together, puzzle-like, the backgrounds and motivations from scenes as they occur. The reward for those who successfully undertake this mission is a sense of how people completely separated in social role, geography, ethics, economic standing, and compelling interests may be affected or outright intertwined by shared events and global phenomenon. This interconnectedness occurs whether the characters are aware of it or not, and whether or not they have any control over their circumstances, much as it does in real life. Each person's kindnesses or cruelties can have a far-reaching impact, outside the vision of the initiator, and no film I've seen has been as successful in illustrating this point as Syriana.All the aforementioned tangents do add together, their vector sum forming a clear direction of plot motion in which seemingly minor events are part of a larger web of causality. In order to establish this web in the finite allotted time, Syriana sacrifices some of the developmental conveniences to which many audience members are accustomed in movies for a detailed, densely-filled, far-reaching script. What one stands to gain from this movie will be proportional to the effort one invests in understanding it. When Syriana becomes available as a DVD, there will be greater potential to mitigate the negative opinions of some who didn't "get it" on the first pass but are open-minded enough to give the film a second viewing at a cheaper price.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>In the congestion of big budget blockbusters, formulaic horror flicks, and unnecessary remakes that 2005 was choked with, Syriana is a breath of fresh air. Centering on the oil industry's impact across the globe, Syriana doesn't really tell us anything new, but still tells an exciting and fascinating story. Intertwining stories include a Persian prince's bid to beat out his brother in taking the throne, a CIA agent uncovering the truth about his career and his agency, a lawyer trying to negotiate a merger between two oil powerhouses, an energy analyst trying to overcome a tragedy, and a young Pakistani man who is let go of his job at an oil plant and gets involved with an extremist group. Most critics think the stories are too confusing and too numerous, but each is important to the big picture and if you pay attention, the movie isn't that hard to follow. And once you understand it, you will be rewarded with one of the best told stories in a long time.The cast is top notch with George Clooney giving the performance of his career. Gone are his suave looks and witty lines, replaced by a scraggly beard, beer belly, and an unsure-of-himself demeanor. Scene stealer Alexander Siddig portrays the headstrong and sincere prince with a quiet explosiveness, and Matt Damon is better than i thought he would be as the energy analyst. Chris Cooper, Jeffery Wright, Christopher Plummer, and Tim Blake Nelson are just a fraction of the excellent supporting cast. Writer/director Stephen Gaghan makes an outstanding debut (i am not counting Abandon only because i haven't seen it) with one of the best movies of the 2005, and one of the most important films in years. 8/10</fullReview>

With five intertwining stories - a CIA agent in Beruit, a financial analyst, a rising prince in a country with a lot of oil, a pair of oil companies merging to get that oil and the problems with that and a young Muslim man who is laid off and falls to a radical sect of the religion. As the tag line suggests, each of these stories are connected, and the filmmakers do an outstanding job making each of these stories fall into place, little by little. Parts of one storyline affect the others in a number of ways. The movie also sports a very talented and outstanding cast, with some in what I thought were some of the best acting jobs that they've done in a while. Directorialwise, we see an outstanding job with the camera, looking over oil rigs, cities, roadways, and moving to some very frantic, shaky camera work. It all falls into place and works outstandingly when and where needed. Highly recommended, although be warned, it's highly political and fairly complicated. I think that I'm going to need another viewing or two to get everything straight.</fullReview>

And that might explain why so many reviewers who oppose its message have given the film just one star. Cinematically the film deserves at least 7. Add to that its much needed and brave political statement and it jumps to 8. But I've given it 9 for a reason that will, most likely, go unnoticed by most American and Western reviewers. This film is breath taking in its meticulous accuracy in presenting some of Middle Eastern culture aspects.I was born and raised in the Middle East in a country not very unlike Syriana. When I watched the movie the first time, I was so convinced that the director must be an Arab that my eyes fooled me when I read his name the first time. 		<fullReview>My test for a good movie is simple - if you're still thinking about it the next day, and discovering things about the plot which passed you by when you saw it, it's worth seeing. Syriana is a dense movie. You need to pay attention to myriad characters, seemingly unconnected subplots and avoid trying to second-guess what will happen. Well-made political thrillers rarely turn out the way the audience expects. The plot twists and changing agendas of the characters are what distinguish the inventive movie from the mundane. It's always nice to have an "Aha!" moment. It happens so rarely. Fine performances and direction make this a movie for grown-ups.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Intentionally confusing?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As with most reviewers here, I came out of the movie theater after seeing Syriana muttering under my breath, "What was that about?" After much thought, it occurred to me that the filmmakers must either be incredibly naive to think that their audience would be able to make sense of this movie, or they fully intended for the audience to be confused. I may be giving them the benefit of the doubt here, but with veterans like George Clooney, Christopher Plummer and William Hurt in the cast, I'm inclined to think the filmmakers knew what they were doing. Which begs the question, Why? I don't claim to know the answer, but it may be that what the filmmakers were trying to get across to us is the reality that there is no sense to be made of the oil mess. When greed, power, fear, blind nationalism and money guide men's actions, logic and morality are left out in the cold. And the webs of entanglement that have been spun between nations, corporations, intelligence agencies, and the wealthy in pursuit of oil are such that it is probably impossible to sort out the relationships. The good guys turn into bad guys, the bad guys turn into good guys (momentarily at least), and everyone is left with an oily residue.This is not a movie for those who like their morality plays cut and dried with an obvious message. This is a movie intended to leave its viewers with bad tastes in their mouths, with the realization that we are all players in this game. With any luck, some of those viewers will buy Toyota Priuses instead of SUVs the next time they purchase a vehicle.</fullReview>
