		<username>tfrizzell</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Black Gold and Traffic Jams.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Excellent in every way, "Syriana" is as vast as the Sahara Desert and as expansive as the deepest ocean. A juggling chess match of near epic proportions in the Academy Award winning style of "Traffic" (perhaps the finest film of the past 25 years), "Syriana" deals with the world's most valuable and important resource---oil. A merger between two powerful U.S. companies reaches not only Houston, but also Washington, D.C. as an ambitious corporate lawyer (Jeffrey Wright) tries to finesse his way to super-stardom. Chris Cooper is the most notable name in a faceless crowd of big business wildcatters who only seem to care about the all mighty dollar. Big name attorneys Christopher Plummer and Tim Blake Nelson also play major roles in the potential merge. Meanwhile, an American power broker (Matt Damon) in the Middle East rubs shoulders with the oldest son (Alexander Siddig) of an elderly king (Nadim Sawalha). Damon finds Siddig to be strangely charismatic and highly intelligent while Siddig's younger brother (Akbar Kurtha) makes it a point to gain his father's kingdom at any cost. Simultaneously Damon has marital difficulties with wife Amanda Peet as the couple suffers an unimaginable tragedy. The potential oil merge in the U.S. leads to a Middle Eastern youngster (Mazhar Munir) finding refuge with a militant religious organization where terrorism appears to be the order for the day. And established CIA operative George Clooney (in his very best role) slowly begins to uncover an elaborate plot that will shake the very foundation that all the key players unwittingly stand on. Writer-director Stephen Gaghan's screenplay is a dizzying exercise that could make your head spin. Taking pages out of films like "JFK" and "Traffic", Gaghan gives the audience lots to digest in a relatively short period of time. Though not preachy, the film points lots of fingers in many different directions and creates an element of understanding with its wide range of personalities. The movie treats the world as a village and not as countries divided by thin lines on maps and globes. Honest, thought-provoking, smart and memorable in every way, "Syriana" is one of those movies that takes no prisoners and makes no apologies. 5 stars out of 5.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-12-24</date>
		<username>omissionsoftheomen</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>An important juxtaposition of two distinct, yet equally desperate societies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have been introducing this movie to friends with the following analogy: recalling the writing adage "Show, don't tell", if you recognise "Bowling For Columbine" as the "tell", this is the "show".By this comparison I am not referring so much to plot as to format and structure: as an effective vessel for political themes, the didactic nature of Moore's work pales, splutters, and dies in the face of storytelling like this. The screenplay for "Syriana" is a welcome throw-back to the 70s and further, back to when cinematic features were not expected to spell out every little detail for their audiences, but instead to throw the viewer in medias res, such that what happens on screen is truly absorbed like a good novel. Yes, the viewer has to do a little more work with this film in order to comprehend what's going on, but even if the viewer chooses not to put in that effort, to let the film wash over him, he won't be disappointed.Moreover, this movie manages to convey our global political environment (the impressions therein) in a way that does not condemn either "side", but simply illustrates (through juxtaposition) the complex differences and similarities between Middle Eastern, "grassroots" terrorism, corporate terrorism, and corruption in two opposing forms of government. "Syriana" is not so much a critique of contemporary global society as it is a call to arms for citizens everywhere to consider how integral propaganda is to our lives, and the tremendous cost these biases can bring to people we don't even know.Some critics disliked that much of the character development in this piece had to be inferred (happening between scenes more often than not), but I personally think this shows they've misunderstood the point of the movie (and also that they probably hated the book "One Hundred Years of Solitude"). Think about it: in a movie that seeks to encapsulate the motivations of whole industries, governments, and classes - and to illustrate how easily individuals (regardless of position or class) become pawns in the larger scheme of things - the conflict must necessarily be external. To demand otherwise, in my opinion, suggests too rigid an adherence to the Western "lone hero" archetype - an archetype that certainly should not apply to movies trying to convey the overarching story of two distinct cultures. Indeed, there are no winners in this movie, for even when an individual does succeed, he does so at the cost of his society.All in all, I found "Syriana" to be a very intelligent piece, with loads of room to welcome back repeat viewers - if less for the viewer who just wants to shut his brain off for a couple hours. Though "thriller" is certainly a misnomer for this piece, anyone with any interest in world affairs will find in this movie a daring and long-awaited means of grappling with the many forces, themes, suspicions and needs that drive contemporary society. At its best, "Syriana" is truly the beginning of a long-awaited cinematic discourse on the world as we know it; my only hope is that the movies to follow in its footsteps will be up to the challenge.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-12-12</date>
		<username>Michael Margetis (pmargetis@cox.net)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>"Corruption. Corruption is our protection, corruption keeps us safe and warm, corruption is why we win." - Danny Dalton</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of the biggest debates going on in the United States right now is our situation in and with Iraq. Should we be over there? Should we take their oil? Should we be engaged in war? All these are questions 'Syriana' doesn't answer and I admire that. I was very skeptical going into first time Oscar-winning screenplay writer Stephen Gaghan's (a big-time liberal from what I've heard) political picture surrounding the conflicts involving U.S. oil companies and the C.I.A. in the Middle-East. 'Syriana' could have been a whiny Liberal Anti-Republican Down with Bush piece, but it wasn't and I admire that. Gaghan makes the wise decision of not choosing sides but just throwing characters and situations out there and letting you figure out who the bad guys or good guys are. 'Syriana' is a fascinating and extremely accurate motion picture in relation to how US oil companies do business. It should be up for some Oscars come March.'Syriana' plays out a lot like Gaghan's 'Traffic' (the best film of 2000) only with a little less violence and explosions. The story has a complex gang of characters starting with an old but sill strong C.I.A. operative, Bob Barnes (George Clooney) who is doing some espionage work in the Middle-East. During his time over there he uncovers a conspiracy involving the C.I.A., which surrounds a young aspiring oil broker, Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon) and an aspiring young Prince (Alexander Siddig) who is anxious to take over his dying dad's throne. Bob gets in-to-deep and is sold out by the C.I.A. That's about all I'll tell you about the plot because 'Syriana' is a film that really needs to be experienced first-person. The film also stars Jeffrey Wright as a sly big-name oil company lawyer, Chris Cooper as a sneaky oil company representative, Nicky Henson as Wright's boss, William Hurt as Clooney's old co-worker and mentor, Mazhar Munir as a young and bright Middle- Eastern boy who is brainwashed into a life of terrorism, Jayne Atkins as Clooney's division chief, Thomas McCarthey as Clooney's co-worker, Amanda Peet as Damon's wife (whose part isn't enticing to say the least), Christopher Plummer as the top dog of the US Oil Company and Tim Blake Nelson as Danny Dalton as a Texas oil tycoon who delivers a powerful speech to Wright's character towards the middle of the film that pretty much sends the message of the entire film.'Syriana' doesn't hold it's punches in being straight-forward and honest, and one has to admire and respect that. Gaghan provides a powerhouse knock-out screenplay that is sure to pick up an Academy Award Nomination. I was also pleasantly surprised with his directing abilities (this was his directorial debut). One of the most stellar aspects surrounding the motion picture is it's numerous stellar performances. Clooney provides what is absolutely the performance of his career as Bob Barnes (who was the author of the novel the movie is based upon). Matt Damon is solid for the most part, while Jeffrey Wright is stunning as a cutthroat lawyer. Christopher Plummer, Chris Cooper and William Hurt are excellent in their roles no matter how small, and Tim Blake Nelson is perfectly cast in his tiny but incredibly important role. Mazhar Munir gives us one of the best youth performances in recent years while Alexander Siddig is delightfully seedy and nerve-wracking as the wannabe King. The only disappointing performance is from Amanda Peet which is in part due the fact her role is very unimportant and also in part due the fact that she is a terrible actress. But besides some very minor flaws, 'Syriana' scorches and compels. The film unfortunately drags a lot around the middle which is why I can't call it a 'masterpiece' and award it an 'A'.I highly recommend 'Syriana' for those who want their beliefs and mind to be challenged. 'Syriana' doesn't spell everything out for you and that's part of it's brilliance. 'Syriana' forces and dares you to think and draw your own conclusions instead of being spoon-fed them like most movies unfortunately end up doing now days. I personally think 'Syriana' should score Oscar nominations for Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Film Editing, Best Sound, Best Supporting Actor - for either Clooney or Wright, and possibly, Best Picture. It's not only one of the most mesmerizing motion pictures of the year but also one of the most pre-eminent ones. If you think you're game, catch it while it's still in theaters. Grade: A- (screened at AMC Desert Ridge 18, Scottsdale, Arizona, 12/10/05)</fullReview>

		<fullReview>From a production quality viewpoint, this film was quite good for a relatively low budget independent. Acting, editing, camera work, etc. were first class. During the film a lot of relevant details go by so fast and are so little explained that the informed viewer who catches a glimpse of them is inclined to give the film makers the benefit of the doubt.I know a great deal about the world this movie purports to address, not as a player, but as an independent investigator with international sources. (Please don't shout at me like that!) For instance, if the movie is really talking about the oil industry term "Syriana," then a large area of central Asia is involved, running all the way from the Persian Gulf states through Kazakhistan in the North. That being the case, where are the Russians in this movie? The Russians are major players in this business on all levels and they are not even represented. Also, no Pakistani had to go to Saudi Arabia to learn about Islamic Fundamentalism from a Wahabi; there are plenty of madrasas in Pakistan preaching a similar ideology. Where is the Pakistani factor in this film? Where is the reference to the development of terrorists by the Pakistan for service in the Kashmir? Since that story led DIRECTLY to the events of 9/11, it would have seemed of interest to have included it. Also, where is the story of the Unical Pipeline from Usbekistan through Afghanistan and the Baluchistan area of Pakistan to the Persian Gulf? That was a major factor of direct US meddling that led to the current situation which the movie was trying to portray. Also, there is no indication that the film makers knew anything about the looooong-standing relationship between the current government of Iran and certain sections of the US Republican Party. Also, in the name of all that's holy, how can you make a movie that has an anti-Iranian group based in the US and leave out the Israelis? Let Iran get close to having nuclear weapons and you will see what I mean.And finally, you don't need a shaped charge to bring down an LNG tanker. All you need is a charge sufficient to penetrate the double hull opposite a tank; the LNG that begins to leak (at -400 degrees plus) would do the rest. The explosion would be inevitable, enormous, and about 20 minutes later (given the ambient high temperature).I am afraid it would take many movies to tell the story of "Syriana," perhaps more than the average film-goer would care to sit through. However, the continued ignorance of the world to what is really going on there will lead to more events that will get everyone's attention.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A fictional movie with the soul of a documentary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the best movie you will see this year that will not win an Oscar. It is very realistic and hard to classify, and therefore will shamefully be overlooked. In the spirit of movies such as "Traffic", it simultaneously follows several story lines, ranging from the corporate politics of Washington to the immigrant worker struggles in the middle east. Though this style of film has been seemingly overdone in the past several years, Syriana manages to achieve a much more realistic viewpoint without even the use of excessive hand-held cameras or special lighting. It is also surprisingly unpretentious. Before seeing the movie I thought it would simply be a liberal slam against big corporations, but it proves to be much more thoughtful than that. The line is blurred between Democrat and Republican, liberal and conservative, antitrust law and capitalist patriotism. The movie's real message is that things are messed up because too many individual interests are involved and good, honest people are working for both sides. The movie can move slow for someone who isn't interested in politics, but if you are willing to pay close attention you will appreciate a movie that is way beyond anything Hollywood is currently shelling out.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not perfect, but stands out in a season of dreck</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana makes you shut up and think. It's a big plate of spaghetti and you will follow some individual story strands for quite a while before you know why.But it all comes together in the end.Movie buffs will react again and again as familiar faces crop up -- solid and underused actors; actors you can't get enough of... and a few new actors who make solid impressions. Among the former groups, David Clennon, Tim Blake Nelson, William Hurt... Only a couple of the parts were played a bit sketchily, and I suspect, thinking about it afterward, that there were likely more than a handful of deleted scenes. It's not that we're missing any of the story line, but we may be missing some of the character story arcs.A lot happens in this movie. Still more lies under the surface. But the through-line here is the notion of "using." People are used, laws are used, money is used, deceit is used... and under it all, oil is used. Oil is the unstated addiction that drives the actions of Our Hero. But he's not really aware of how high the mechanism of providing for oil reaches until late in the game. Invisible strings make regimes happen, make alliances happen; make death happen. And it's all in the service of the global need for oil. Is the current and future hunger for oil an addiction, or is it the lifeblood of civilization? That's a question you won't find in this film, but it should hit you some time afterward as you reflect on what you've seen. The other thing that should hit you afterward is: if anything is worth fighting and dying for, isn't it oil?Syriana has a moral point to make, but it's a simple one and not steeped in any particular ideology: we pay an (often unintended) price for our actions. The link between our actions and the price paid is a long, tortured, probably even invisible link. But Syriana shows one aspect of the price to us.The secondary moral is that incredible wealth can be a curse --- especially if that wealth is a vital resource.Earlier this year, "Lord of War" seemingly attempted a similar revelation about another industry. but where LoW seemed simplistic and preachy with over-the-top action and acting, Syriana is a great story, well played, and enjoyable just for what's on the surface. The moral components are only there for your personal reflections to uncover.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A messy, unconvincing narrative that drags along undoes what should have been a slick and impacting condemnation of oil and politics</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Obviously it depends on your politics but those who share mine say that we are in Iraq because of the West's demand for oil. They say that top US politicians are in bed with the Saudi Royal family because of oil. They say that corruption is rife within the corridors of power in regards oil dealing and even that those who demand oil for their sports utility vehicles are guilty of funding terrorists by not controlling their consumption. Now, given that this is a subject that we all believe to be swimming in corruption and shady going-ons, you do have to wonder why Gaghan was not able to pull it together into a tighter, more meaningful and more impacting narrative.Many of the professional reviews I have read for this film have complained that the stories are hard to connect and that it gave you the feeling you'd walked in late and missed something; however the same reviews also forgive this by saying "maybe that was the point". Well, maybe it was but that is not an excuse for having a film that is about two hours long that only starts to come together towards the end. It does not forgive the subplots that don't add value or the scenes that don't fit simply because the script doesn't tell us until the end how it is going to work. Of course the film still engaged me because the individual threads were all interesting even if their relevance or direction was not always clear, but it was a problem for me that they were so disconnected ? and that may well be the point but it doesn't make for a great film. Equally disappointing was how simplistic the connection ultimately was and how obvious the point made were; again, maybe it is because we all assume these things to be true that this was not an eye-opener and shocking condemnation that it should have been.Many viewers will struggle to get into a film that seems intent on pushing the viewer away. We are given things that seem to go nowhere, stories that don't seem to connect, characters we are not allowed to understand and we are left wondering when it will get to the place we know it is all going. It is still worth a look though because individual scenes are great and even the individual threads have enough to make them interesting but it is just such a shame that all these little things don't come together very well. As director Gaghan has done a great job because the film looks great, moves nicely and looks really professional. Likewise the cast are impressive in their presence as well as performances (on the whole) if you ignore the limitations the materials serves them with. Clooney is impressive and it is not his fault that his character doesn't totally make sense. Plummer relishes his powerful old man but Wright doesn't seem to know what to do with his and he seems to either have it all going on inside his head or he just didn't understand what he was doing. Damon is good but again I don't think he saw how he was meant to fit in. Support from Peet, Waked, Cooper, Foxworth, Novak and others is all fine but they cannot overcome the problems inherent in the story and the telling.Overall then this is worth seeing but fell way short of my expectations. It looks great and the cast are all good on paper and on screen but the narrative problems just completely undercut it for me. I know that Gaghan was going for a tapestry of stories to all come together but he didn't pull it off and instead of being one impressive tapestry it is a patchwork quilt ? bits of it are good but stand back from it and it all works disjointed and messy. Interesting but nowhere near good enough to be compared to Traffic, which does the same thing but actually pulls it off.</fullReview>

		<username>(roland@atkinsononfilm.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Humdinger of an action film about skullduggery to control oil and politics in Southwest Asia</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Syriana" is a vast, teeming, mile-a-minute, kaleidoscopic, whirlwind story about the geopolitical, economic and clandestine military (terrorist and counter-terrorist) forces that are in play in the international race to control oil supplies and the future fortunes and political allegiances of Southwest Asia and the Middle East.Stephen Gaghan, the screenwriter and (first time) director of "Syriana," who previously wrote the scripts for "Rules of Engagement," "Traffic" and "The Alamo," relishes complexity in his narratives. In "Traffic," a film about drug trafficking from Mexico into the southwest U.S., we followed three sizable sets of characters in three locales, flipping, often at a fast pace, among them. "Traffic's" director, Steven Soderbergh, took compassion upon viewers of that film by color coding scenes for the three story arcs. Now, in "Syriana," we have just as many characters to contend with, if not more, some of whom look a lot alike (I'm thinking not only here of the Arabs but also of our own middle aged, beefy white guys), operating in a dozen or so locales, and there's no color coding to help us out this time.Accordingly, the rap on "Syriana" has been that it is too difficult to understand and follow the story lines, that one is snowed by the weight of it all, and that you have to go back and see it again at least one more time to get things straight. Well, I think that view misses the point. I don't think Mr. Gaghan wants us to get the plot details down pat. His point of view, I surmise, is precisely that there is so much going on in the world at any given moment in connection with the issues at hand, so much contradictory activity or at least 180 degree rapid turnabouts by one party or another, so much disinformation and denial of the truth by various government and corporate spokespersons, that the whole notion of "getting the story straight" is in itself absurdly na?ve.George Clooney, as Bob Barnes, who is apparently a high level CIA operative, skillfully leads a huge and splendid cast that also features Jeffrey Wright (as Bennett Holiday, Jr., a lawyer, for the Justice Dept., I think) and Matt Damon (Bryan Woodman, a private economic adviser) in prominent roles, and includes a huge band of cameo players, the most memorable of whom are (in alpha order): Chris Cooper (Jimmy Pope, a Texas oilman), William Charles Mitchell (Bennett Holiday, Sr., a seriously compromised alcoholic), Tim Blake Nelson (Danny Dalton, I never did get his job straight), Amanda Peet (Julie Woodman, Bryan's wife), Christopher Plummer (Dean Whiting, a rich bigshot of some sort), Alexander Siddig (Prince Nasir Al-Subaai, a smart fellow who would lead his Emirate nation well, but because of this, is opposed by a bunch of interests), Mark Strong (Mussawi, a terrorist torturer) and Amr Waked (Mohammed Sheik Agiza, a terrorist leader).My advice to those who have not yet seen this movie is, first, do see it. It's a humdinger of an action flick, based (at least loosely) upon real events and people, contained in the source book, "See No Evil: The True Story of a Ground Soldier in the CIA's War on Terrorism," by Robert Baer. Second, see it once, but discard your obsessive need to master plot details at the box office window. Think of the film as more of an impressionistic pastiche. Relax into it, if you can, and let the events in the movie just flow through you. Whatever prejudices you've ever harbored about lying, cheating, stealing, duplicity, corruption, profiteering, dirty tricks and every other sort of skullduggery sponsored by individuals, agencies, nations, corporations and guerrilla insurgents afoot in the world will be sharply reinforced by watching this film. (In English, Urdu, Arabic, Farsi and French). My ratings: 8.5/10 (A-). (Seen on 01/21/06). If you'd like to read more of my reviews, send me a message for directions to my websites.</fullReview>

		<username>Rathko</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Confusing, Fascinating, and Believable</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Syriana' presents a confusing, fascinating, and believable dramatization of the moral and political quagmire of the modern oil industry. Following several characters whose paths rarely cross but whose actions effect each other in unexpected ways, the storyline is a dizzying, expressionistic blur of names, acronyms, organizations, and datelines. Connections and motives are more suggested than stated, though bizarrely, by the movie's end, there is a sense that the narrative has progressed logically and inevitably to its climax.The problem with the multi-thread narrative is that no character is ever singled out as the protagonist. The audience is not given anyone to really identify and connect with. If a 2-hour movie presents six separate story lines, then each storyline can only be granted 20 minutes of screen time. Twenty minutes simply isn't long enough to develop characters, establish their goals, and engage us in their struggle. The structure of such stories will always create an emotional distance, and it's one that is almost impossible to bridge. To Gaghan's credit, he creates as much empathy for his characters as is possible within the constraints of his structure, but not enough to make the climax as tragic as it should be.Filmed in Morocco and the United Arab Emirates, many scenes have an unusually authentic sense of location, and it is refreshing to see an honest depiction of the Middle East in a mainstream movie. There are no real enemies here, just individuals fighting for what they believe is their survival, and it's hard to imagine conservatives or liberals arguing with such a mature depiction of politics, global business and terrorism.'Syriana' is worth seeing, and what it reveals about the hidden connections and relationships between the involved parties is fascinating and eye-opening. But Gaghan's insistence on such a fragmented departure from traditional film narrative prevents any real sense of engagement, and the result is cold and clinically impersonal.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Austin Movie Show review - dense, challenging, and brilliant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is dense (to say the least) and necessitates a second viewing ? but that's a good thing! Most Hollywood movies pander to a lazy, illiterate, uninformed American audience, but Syriana does the opposite. This movie demands that its audience step up and critically think about what it's watching.The story starts with oil. Connex, a major oil company in Houston, want to merge with Killen, a minor oil company that just acquired rights to oilfields in the former Soviet state of Kazakhstan. If this merger is approved, the new company will have more money than Denmark and become the 27th largest economy in the world. Meanwhile, a group of poor oilfield workers in Iran have lost their jobs because of the merger, and with no work and nowhere to go, they turn to an Islamic school for food and shelter. One of the students in this school has bought a missile from a CIA agent in Iran.That CIA agent is then sent to Syria to assassinate an Iranian prince and retrieve the missing weapon. This Iranian prince is moderate, educated, wants democracy in Iran, and is first in line to inherit the thrown from his father, the Emir. However, since he has allowed China into Iran to do business, the American government views him as a terrorist and doesn't want him to inherit the thrown. His brother, however, wants the thrown as well, and is more easily persuaded by the American government to allow American troops and businesses in Iran and therefore has the support and backing of the most powerful country in the world.No, it's not easy to follow, but it's all connected. Not one country, company, or character is blameless. Everyone is corrupt and everyone is looking out for their own best interest. It's not all about oil, but it is all about money, and when an American politician tells you that we're invading another country to liberate it, don't be so naive.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>It is difficult to pick apart America's strategy in the Middle East without becoming preachy, but this film manages it with an understated finesse. It will not please everyone, mind. Syriana does not contain the action scenes you might associate with George Clooney or Matt Damon and its split narratives do not lead to a life-affirming conclusion. Nor will it cut any ice with patriots wedded to the idea of America's role as the liberator of the Middle East. But none of this makes it a bad film.True, it can be a mite confusing. It took me a while to work out what, or who, George Clooney's CIA agent was meant to be doing when he is sent to Beirut. But momentary confusion does little to obscure the function of the film - a masterclass in American foreign policy in the Middle East.The film, wisely, does not mention Iraq. To do so would enter a debate that has become so polarised as to be meaningless. It gives a broader picture, and by doing so exposes the paradox in American (and British) policy towards the Middle East. While we in the West do believe that democracy is a way of stabilising countries and bringing them into the global economy, it is a double-edged sword. If Arab leaders are elected, they have legitimacy in the eyes of their people. The more legitimacy they have, the less they must rely on Western military support to prop up their regimes.What Syriana illustrates so eloquently is that when it comes down to a choice, America would rather have despotic Arab leaders it can push around than liberal-minded reformists who would be free to negotiate oil deals with, say, China. It is not a choice without consequences, the film argues. Which leader, the despot or the reformist, is more likely to preside over a society that fosters terrorists?The performances by George Clooney, Matt Damon, Chris Cooper, Jeffrey Wright et al are spot on. There is no showboating, just solid, close to the knuckle acting. It is more "political" than "thriller", but if that doesn't put you off then you will find Syriana a rewarding and thought-provoking experience.</fullReview>
	</review>

Syriana is ultimately a figurative and literal nail-biter in which allegiances fade most sadly between parents and children while oil runs through them.The left turn at the film's conclusion shows where Clooney and Company's heart is, although they've tried to be balanced between left and right throughout. Like Clooney's Good Night, and Good Luck, the Edward R. 		<username>David H. Schleicher</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Trafficking Oil and Preaching to the Converted</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>2005 has been a great year for politically charged films, ranging from old-fashioned highly fictionalized throw-back thrillers like "The Interpreter", to searing, romantic and artistically astute literary adaptations like "The Constant Gardner" to quiet and classy period pieces with timely morals like "Good Night, and Good Luck." "Syriana" arrives late on the scene like gangbusters purporting to be the gritty no-holds-bar thriller that will shine light on the shady underside of our current energy crisis.Though ultimately a bit of a disappointment, "Syriana" is still far better than the Stephen Gaghan penned "Traffic"-the overrated, over-long multi-layered intertwining episode about the "War on Drugs." Here Gaghan serves as both writer and director, and given the current state of geopolitics, the subject matter here of terrorism, corruption, and oil trafficking is far more compelling and timely than his previous Oscar-winning effort.Though extremely well acted and marginally well made, "Syriana" suffers because it presents scenarios liberal-minded Americans already know too well thanks to movies like "Farhenheit 9/11" and the continued follies of the current Bush administration. Here we have greedy American oil companies and corrupt politicians putting in place a puppet regime in the Middle East to protect their interests and prevent the Chinese from gaining access to the energy source their burgeoning economy so badly needs. We also have the tale of a grizzled CIA operative (the excellent George Clooney) getting outed, a slick energy analyst (an equally good Matt Damon) looking to cash in on "the winning horse" in a fraternal power struggle for the Saudi crown, and a legal investigator (the underwhelming Jeffrey Wright) pegged to bring down some devious insiders as a PR sideshow designed to give the illusion of due diligence and deter people from seeing the true corruption behind all these overt mergers and acquisitions and covert assassinations.There are some white-knuckle moments, but the film relies on cheap manipulations (failed father-son relationships, a strained marriage, and the accidental death of child) to play on the audience's emotions. Ultimately none of these characters are very sympathetic because of these lame ploys, although there is an interesting side story about some suicide bombers that could've been more developed and should've provided the emotional core the film so badly wanted to create. Ultimately, the film depicts things we all know too well and offers no solutions to the problems. For all its supposed revelations it left me with a feeling of "so what?" because it never tried to make a statement about what we should do to curtail all this evil-doing.Side Note: Amanda Peet, the most underrated and misused actress of her generation, is excellent as Matt Damon's wife. Her brief screen time displays her natural charms and her ability to carry heavy drama. Here's hoping her agent convinces her to do more stuff like this instead of the inane comedies she normally finds herself headlining.</fullReview>

And we see how greed for money and power defy logic and cause governments to act against their own interests, and people to act against one another.The acting is superb in this film. 		<shortDescription>The Price of War ala "Traffic"; One of the Year's Absolute Best Films</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SYRIANA (2005) **** George Clooney, Matt Damon, Jeffrey Wright, Amanda Peet, William Hurt, Christopher Plummer, Chris Cooper, Mazhar Munir, Robert Foxworth, Peter Gerety, Tim Blake Nelson, Alexander Siddig, Nadim Sawalha, Akbar Kurtha. The Price of War ala "Traffic"; One of the Year's Absolute Best FilmsThe state of the world today is no secret: it's a mess and largely full of blood and oil both equaling out to a quagmire of sand and despair in the Middle East where the geopolitical climate is at the boiling point of madness seeking sanity and in the end starting all over again where you began : a mirage of good intentions.Filmmaker Stephen Gaghan , who garnered an Academy Award for his multi- storied screenplay for "Traffic", incorporates more-or-less the same dichotomy for his pulse-pounding potboiler of international intrigue and human drama. Gaghan, who directs as well as written the intriguingly absorbing and dense screenplay, manages to keep several pots cooking to a fine boil by focusing on a disillusioned CIA op (a bearish Clooney in arguably his finest acting to date and should earn him an Oscar nod); an idealistic systems analyst (Damon at the top of his game); a scruples laden Washington, DC based attorney brooking to make waves and a name for himself (Wright, also in fine form) and an imploding young Arab desperate to make a living for himself (Munir).Gaghan lets all four story lines stray and finally intertwine into a fine tapestry of human turmoil as each protagonist faces the one universal truth: fear is a powerful thing and greed is a close second. Clooney's world-weary, bearded Bob Barnes (based loosely on real-life spook Robert Baer whose book Gaghan has adapted to his form-fitting production) is attempting to do the right thing in bringing to light the underpinnings of a Middle Eastern Emir about to abdicate his ruling to one of his sons, a prince who may have other agendas including monopolizing the world's oil conglomerates including one that Damon's young Bryan Woodman works for who's invite to the prince's palatial digs tragically ends for his youngest child in a horrible pool- related accident at a party the Emir has thrown. To show his respect the prince decides to give Woodman a significant amount of business and money; Woodman's slight weariness is only outweighed by his cynicism ("How much will you give me for my other son?" he sneers at first to the generous offering).Meanwhile Bennett Holiday (Wright) is attempting to find some loose fissures in another oil company in attempting to find a scapegoat for any loop-hole evading machinations that frankly is a tad confusing yet the results are anticipated whole-heartedly (and nicely skewered by a corrupt oilman played by a weaselly Nelson who gives a Gordon Gekko-ian speech that only rings too true for the idealistic Holiday).Munir proves to be the one recognizable Arab stereotype of a young man facing his metaphorically manacled character facing little choice except not resisting a zealotry leading to terrorism that is probably all too likely so true as well.Tightly constructed with a fierce grip on the worldwide pulse of current events, Gaghan and company displays a real social study in harvesting a global communities' dream and curse: attempting to do the right thing in a tempest in tea cup that is only continuing to gain momentum.</fullReview>

		<username>Greg (gregmoroberts@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great film - if you can keep up</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At the end of Syriana, when the credits began to roll and the lights slowly relit the capacity seated theatre, I sat in my seat for what must have been an eternity just trying to process and interpret what I just saw.Now that is not a bad thing mind you. In fact, five or six hours now removed from the experience, I think it was actually a wonderful frame of mind to be in after just this type of film.What exactly is this type? Well, you have the writer of Traffic who goes behind the camera with a $50 million promisary note from the studio and stars with the last names of Clooney, Damon, Cooper and Plummer being attracted to your screenplay like mosquitoes to a blue light. All signs therefore have this film pointing towards mainstream blockbuster potential. You know, asteroid hitting the earth with dialogue that even your 5-year old nephew would laugh at, but done with pretty people in even prettier locations.But not Syriana. Instead, director Stephen Gaghan (who also wrote the very good Havoc now on DVD), puts up on the big screen maybe one of the most complex and interesting stories that the multiplexes have seen in some time. Nothing therefore is typical about Syriana.To tell you the story would reveal that I have figured it out (I am getting closer..) and that would be a misrepresentation. Here's what I can tell you. Through multiple locations and various story lines, we follow the lives of three central characters. First, there is Bob Barnes (George Clooney). Bob is a government operative who finds himself in places like Beirut and Iran trying to bring American justice to the Middle East. His methods and motives are right out of modern day spy novels complete with denial, deception and torture. When an arms deal goes bad that Bob was arranging, Bob is extracted back to the United States to a desk job in Washington in hopes that the story eventually buries itself.Simultaneously, we have the story of Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon in maybe his strongest performance to date) an economic wondermind that finds himself working for an eventual heir to the Emir throne after his son is accidentally electrocuted in the palace pool. Living with the demons of knowing he is working for those that were indirectly responsible for his son's death, Bryan neglects his remaining family to provide financial advice to the Prince in his attempt to bring stabilization to the regions economy.And while all this is going on abroad, back in the good ole USA, Bennett Holliday (Jeffrey Wright) is the hired hand in a firm investigating the backend dealings of a major oil conglomerate merger. With ties to both resources in both America and the Middle East, this third storyline connects the other two ? not directly, but by highlighting the notion that oil is the primary reason why the West has any interest in the financial or economic well being of the region. Holliday's relentless search for fall guys uncovers a world that that only the most in-depth 60 Minutes investigation could uncover. One with corruption leading to some of the biggest heads of corporate industry and where greed is so accepted that Gordon Gekko might even turn his head in disgust.The result of these stories which somehow intersect is as complex and as gripping a screenplay that Hollywood has likely seen greenlit in some time. The result therefore is mixed. You will unlikely be able to refute that the acting is top rate. Clooney and Damon in particular give maybe the best performances of their careers and their supporting cast is no less stellar.But like reading a Tom Clancy novel, this adaptation of a Robert Baer book (See No Evil: The True Story of a Ground Soldier in the CIA's War on Terrorism) jumps from country to country and storyline to storyline with head turning swiftness where the only way to understand what is probably one of the best movies of the year is to get out of your seat at the end of the film, go back to the box office and buy another ticket to see it all again.www.robertsreviews.com</fullReview>

		<username>notmattdamon83</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Inflammatory, confusing, emotional, and Important.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Syriana" is an inflammatory, confusing, intelligent, emotional, and ultimately important work by the writer of "Traffic". That film wove together four story lines with four different protagonists on different sides of America's War on Drugs. This film acts similarly, weaving together the lives of four men as they navigate the consequences that come about as Western interests stake their claims on the world's ever-dwindling supply of Oil in the Middle East. "Traffic" negotiated its complicated story (which took place in the U.S. and Mexico) by walking clear and understandable moral lines to American audiences: drugs are a terrible evil, but family and loyalty are the ultimate good, and the two poles are not necessarily mutually exclusive. "Syriana" is morally hazier than "Traffic", and plays sort of like the next class up in Big Idea screen writing - "Traffic" is the prerequisite, and if you could follow it no problem, you're probably smart enough for "Syriana".Bob Barnes (George Clooney), a world-worn CIA agent adept at getting his hands dirty in fun locations like Tehran and Beirut, is the first of the four (for lack of a better word) protagonists. Thought to be a liability by his superiors, he's given one last assignment, to arrange the assassination of Prince Nasr (Alexander Siddig), a royal from an unnamed Arab Emirate who awarded an oil contract to the Chinese after they outbid an American company. Bryan Woodman (Matt Damon) is an energy analyst who becomes the economic adviser to Nasr following the tragic death of Woodman's son at the Prince's estate. Meanwhile, back in the U.S., Bennett Holiday (Jeffrey Wright), an attorney for Connex Oil, investigates his superiors in order to get a merger with another company, Killen Oil, approved by the Department of Justice. And, back in the Emirate, a young Pakistani man named Wasim Khan (Mazhar Munir) loses his job at the Connex plant when the Chinese take over, and from his economic hardship becomes seduced into radical Islamic fundamentalism. All of these stories intersect each other as each of these men must make decisions to do the Right thing, or do the most Advantageous thing, in what one character calls "a fight to the death." Ultimately, though, the film has a dark and upsetting message: that it is in the West's business interests not to ignore the hardship and chaos in the Middle East, but to encourage it.Ensemble films often come with their own trouble: not having one single character provides the danger of painting everything with a broad brush. Gaghan twists this by providing all the characters with a moral ambiguity that is at the heart of this film's politics. The scenes between Woodman and his wife Julie (Amanda Peet), as she is horrified at how he is profiting off of the death of their son, are painful and glorious at the same time. The quiet way that Holiday is taken into one-on-one conversations and back rooms and corners by members of the Connex and Killen corporations, each trying to shape the quiet man, complicates what ultimately happens with the merger. Barnes seems to constantly be at war within himself, about whether he's weary of feeling bad for the things he's doing, or just weary of doing the only thing he knows how. The film is also helped by a theme of the disconnect between fathers and sons, reminding me that the best films about business are those in which the young go-getter seeks out another paterfamilias in a world of money when the one at home wasn't sufficient (think "Wall Street").The performances are all very strong. Clooney put on 35 lbs for the film, and hiding behind the weight and the beard allows him to almost hide inside himself, a man who had to literally build a thick skin as he realized how few people could understand the world he lives in. Damon is also strong, playing a character with enough seething energy that, in the hands of another actor, might have come off like a bland everyman or an overplayed twit. Wright and Munir allow themselves a quiet, smart observation--you believe their transformations not because the people around them are charismatic (which they are), but because you can see them being filled up by the new worlds they are entering. There is also fine supporting work, possibly the best coming from Siddig as Prince Nasr, a charismatic leader and tragic hero of the film, and Chris Cooper, the head of Killen Oil, who tears around a Board of Directors meeting reminding everyone why he's the only one in the room who doesn't have to wear an uncomfortable-looking suit.The real central performance, however, is the politics, ideas, and information in the film. At times, the plot points can be a bit confusing as we discover the intricacies of what is going on. This is a good idea, however, because it forces the audience to pay attention to what is going on, allowing them to better absorb the complexities of Oil policy. There are a lot of Big Speeches, but these are people who deal with the Big Picture, and I'd much rather seem smart people making smart points than dumb people talking big for the sake of talking. This film provides an interesting template for films that want to take on complex subjects that affect the whole world. It doesn't just tell interesting stories but opens the audience up to the idea that the world doesn't work in black &amp; white (as it often does in the movies), people do bad things in the Real World, but not always for bad reasons, and people do good things, and the world can be left off in worse shape. With this moral ambiguity and the specificity of the politics and situations, "Syriana" is one of the smartest films I've ever seen. Hollywood should be making more films like this.</fullReview>
	</review>

Ultimately, I think Gaghan is guilty of mistaking a confusing overstuffed narrative for a intriguingly complex one. And his directorial abilities (as evidenced by his underwhelming first effort ABANDON) need honing. The scene with Matt Damon's kid at the pool was so ineptly executed I still don't quite know what transpired, although the tragic outcome was clear. Instead, you watch as the characters move, indelibly, towards an end that is terrible in its inevitability.See this film if you want to understand some home truths about our world and cultures. It is truly remarkable and warrants multiple viewings to catch the subtle nuances of both the story and performances.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>definitely a must-see</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syrianna is a riveting political thriller about a very hot button issue, the oil crisis, that few people really know much about beyond the numbers that appear on gas station billboards. It was released at the right time of year so that its inevitable Oscar buzz considerations will give the material added weight which might have been what the exec producers (including the politically active George Clooney and producing partner Steven Sodebergh) were going for. Still, it's not an overtly political film. It doesn't seek to point fingers at an administration although with our overly polarized political culture today, people are bound to dismiss it as left wing propaganda, and that's unfortunate because a work of art like this deserves to be treated as art rather than politics.The main criticism, as far as I can tell, is that the plot is too complex for the average viewer, but that's partially the point: that the oil crisis is a complex matter and that's why an easy solution isn't in the works. I'll concede that this wasn't necessarily a smart move on the filmmakers' behalf to clutter up the start of the film rather than provide an attention-grabbing opening, but the film gets easier to swallow as it goes along. Matt Damon deals with a strained marriage and the tragedy of his 6-year old son's death but sees an opportunity for an unlikely friendship and business pairing with an enlightened Arab prince. George Clooney plays a CIA operative with an estranged son and wife who treats covert operations and killing like any other 9-to-5 job until he gets betrayed by his government. Jeffery Wright plays a cold and methodical lobbyist hired to find and weed out the corrupt link in an oil merger and he's equally at ease playing a game of racquetball with his suspect as he is calling him out before the board on his corruption. And then there are the two Arab youths looking for jobs who befriend a shady man and eventually become suicide bombers. It's the human dimensions of these stories and the way Stephen Gaughan masterfully weaves them together that make the movie so engaging as the movie moves past a cluttered-up start.Credit director Stephen Gaughan, who is making his directorial debut after winning an Oscar as the screenwriter for Traffic, appears to be a disciple of Stephen Sodebegh's school of film-making, as he copies some of Sodebergh's tricks: showing only parts of conversations to make it appear as though we're coming in midway, on-location shooting with an independent feel, bridging different places together illustrated by text, etc.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>As art, "Syriana" is hardly a great movie. It's slow-paced and borderline boring at times. It strives for understatement and subtlety, but what it offers is an obvious, predictable plot with vague details. It's easy to watch the film and come away not being sure exactly who some of the characters are.Most modern films bend over backwards to explain everything, and this gets old fast. Syriana, unfortunately, strives too hard to go in the opposite direction. It wants to be a cerebral thriller, but the edits cut back and forth between the various characters so fast we never get a feel for who they are.While some viewers may be confused about the details, the basic plot is blindingly obvious and you can see the end coming a mile away. Presumably this film is intended as a criticism of U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East. In "Syriana", the ultimate villains are the oil companies. Chris Cooper, in a fine performance that far outshines Clooney's, plays an oil company executive and delivers a memorable speech about corruption being the best way to do business.I'm not sure how one could view this film as not being political, since it's commenting on U.S. foreign policy in an obvious way, but it's safe to say that if you're conservative, you will find this movie leftist. If you're more liberal, you'll probably see it as scathingly accurate. As for me, politics aside, I found it mostly dull and uninvolving. Given the hype and its Oscar win, it was a big disappointment.As political commentary, it leaves a lot to be desired. As entertainment, it isn't very compelling.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Worthy but Wordy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a thriller 'Syriana' isn't particularly thrilling. It has much of worth to say about the responsibility of the West for the continuing crisis in the Middle East, and about the duplicities of the oil industry, internationally, but the overall tone of Steven Gaghan's script is so polemical and the outcome (in broad terms) predictable that it loses momentum.That's not to say it isn't an entertaining film. It is. There are splendid performances from principals Clooney, Damon, the underrated Jeffrey Wright and Siddig, and superb supporting turns from the likes of Chris Cooper, Tim Blake Nelson, Amanda Peet, William Hurt and (at his most reptilian) Christopher Plummer. The film has much of worth to say about the consequences of American foreign policy with regard to the oil trade and the wilful manipulations of Arab states. There are some electric sequences, too, but ? the occasional explosion aside ? very few surprises. It's too damned expository.Part of the problem concerns the three leading men ? the CIA operative (Clooney), the economic adviser (Damon) and the lawyer investigating possible corruption within the US oil trade (Wright). The first is a patriot who manipulates or murders on the orders of his government, and who is surprised when he is in turn manipulated. The interests of the second are entirely governed by profit. The third seeks corruption, but profits, professionally, from selling out one of his bosses to another. This may, perhaps, be an attempt to signal to audiences that these are not reactionary anti-American caricatures ? the characters all have a vested interest in the status quo ? but they are not particularly likable. Neither are they virtuous or heroic ? though a last-gasp attempt is made to turn Clooney's conflicted agent into such a character ? though even his change of perspective is principally prompted by being made a whipping-boy by his agency rather than altruism. Unfortunately this effort is too little too late, and the character's motivations are rather muddled by the labyrinthine plotting.It's an interesting film, but if I didn't share the liberal politics of the film-makers I don't think I would necessarily have thought so.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Written and directed by Stephen Gaghan - who wrote the screenplay for "Traffic" - this accomplished political thriller owes a lot to George Clooney who both acts as an executive producer and takes on the key role (for which he put on 35lb in a month but won an Academy Award) of embittered CIA agent Bob Barnes (a reference to Robert Baer who wrote the novel on which the movie is based).There are multiple story lines, characters and locations, so that one frequently struggles to understand what is going on and how each element relates to all the others, but there is fine acting - with familiar faces such as Matt Damon, Chris Cooper, Christopher Plummer &amp; William Hurt as well as opportunities for able Arab actors - and the sort of cinematography that draws one irresistibly into the action.At times the message is thumped home too bluntly (there is a little speech concluding "Corruption is why we win"), but this indictment of the machinations around the American oil industry and its political backers is compelling and challenging cinema - as well as uncomfortably topical.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A testament to what could have been...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana was one of the most claustrophobic movie-going experiences of my life, so in that detail I can honestly call it memorable: in all other respects it fails abjectly.The film is marketed as a tense, gritty thriller exposing the corrupt and unscrupulous oil industry of the USA, and its links with the Middle East. However, I can report emphatically that Syriana does not do what it says on the tin. To understand and to be able to wade through the plot requires either a PhD in oil analysis or the attention span and brain capacity of a member of MENSA. It says a lot about a film when you come out unable to remember the names of any characters. And I mean that in a bad way.One of the main problems is that writer-director Stephen Gaghan seems determined to cram into one film enough material for ten. The way in which Gaghan's script flits from place to place means that the audience is never with any character long enough to build up a rapport with them. As a result, Syriana never packs the emotional punch that could have given it the extra edge to make it engrossing.George Clooney puts in a decent performance - quite an achievement considering what he had to work with - but in my opinion he didn't do enough to deserve an Oscar. Matt Damon is steadfast and resolutely wooden: although I don't know how much he can be blamed for that given the aforementioned script malfunction.The direction is not brilliant either. In order the accommodate the more than numerous facets and tributaries of the script Gaghan is inclined to dart from one story line to another in the space of minutes. The result is a choppy mismatch; never in one place long enough to actually work out who anyone is: and shaky camera work that left me feeling more than a little motion sick.I appreciate the message of the film and the issue it is trying to expose, but I left the cinema feeling almost numb because I just didn't care. Joe Viewer is by no means stupid, but even he needs a vaguely comprehensible story line to engross himself in a film. It is obvious that the producers behind Syriana feel very strongly about the subject: however if they are hoping to have created a courageous expose of the nasty oil industry then I am sorry to say they will be disappointed.Syriana is not a bad film, but is a testament to the fact that good intentions do not always equate to a good film. Syriana is a testament to what could have been. With a lot less characters and a marginally less complicated plot, the film could have been a very effective insight into corruption and its effects. But sadly, what it has ended up as is an overcomplicated and uninteresting film that is quite frankly headache inducing.</fullReview>

		<username>gus120970</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Black reign</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Somewhat confusing, sometimes frustrating, Syriana is, for its byzantine entirety a thought-provoking, complex and interesting endeavour. At its centerpiece is the world's most fascinating political and cultural paradox - the world's leading power, largely and ostensibly a liberal and democratic state, and the world's primary energy region, theocratic and inegalitarian, forced by the realities of economics and geopolitics into a scorpion embrace with its immoral counterpart. This is the point we find ourselves in now that fossil fuel production has passed its zenith, and a new ideological battle between Westernism and fundamental Islam has quickly supplanted the brief and ill-defined 'End of History'. What this means for the chess-piece characters of Syriana is compromise, intrigue, each operating in a hall-of-mirrors where, even if the character can see through to his intent, cannot see all its implications, whether it be a military coup, a government whitewash or a missile ramming a gas tanker. The only potential veer towards liberal political simplicity is a perhaps naive portrayal of the Emir's first son - a reformer, but not a Western stooge and therefore subject, Tom Clancy-style to the obligatory Cruise-missile diplomacy which has become a bit of a cliché of American spy films. The CIA is far too subtle to assassinate aspiring heads of state with traceable ship-launched ballistics. The Clooney Lebanon plot is more stylish, and for that matter, teeth-clenchingly entertaining. In the end, we are never quite sure from our suburban perspective, whether this is what spies and terrorists are like, or what the movies like to tell us they're like. But then, bad things are happening to bad people all over the place, so there must be an element of authenticity. You may feel disorientated for the first hour or so, then captivated, and eventually liberated by Syriana.</fullReview>

		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Incoherent, messy story with fine performances</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Steven Gaghan, the scribe responsible for "Rules Of Engangement" (2000) and "Traffic" (2000) confuses us even further in his directorial debut "Syriana" about the vast intertwining tales of the oil industry. George Clooney plays a CIA operative sent to knock off a Persian King-to-be, yet gets more than he bargained for on his journey. Matt Damon plays an energy-analyst mourning the death of his eldest son. Jeffrey Wright is a lawyer sent to investigate the ramifications behind the merger of two oil companies - Connex and Killeen. Mazhar Munir is a Pakistani teenager who falls prey to the recruitment of Terrorism in the Middle East. Each story seems to have a sub-plot involving father/son relationships, and the various struggles each member goes through. As Gaghan points out in the tag line "Everything Is Connected".Gaghan, not the best storyteller in the world, deliberately withholds information from his audience in order to throw surprises at us. There are moments of true shock in Syriana, yet the story itself is hard to follow anyway. To explain the plot in detail would be a futile exercise. The basic outlines are all there, everyone plays a part in the desperation of the USA's dependence on foreign oil. Gaghan is implying that the US is willing to stretch and/or break the law in order to continue it's stranglehold on the middle east. But as a piece of dramatic entertainment it just doesn't work. Political thrillers that overcome their own complexities, Michael Mann's The Insider being a great example, are ones that offer emotional access as well as intelligent design. His heart is certainly in the right place, and he clearly has the talent at his disposal. But trying to figure out the various over-circuitous story lines in "Syriana" gave me more than just a headache.George Clooney won a deserved Oscar for his portrayal of an ageing CIA agent who struggles with his son and is manipulated by his own government. Indeed, the whole cast do their best, but in the end, you are left feeling hollow. "Syriana" relays a message that we already agree with, and does it intelligently and well-played. But it just doesn't involve it's audience enough to truly outrage, or even effect us. An intelligent, weighty, yet ultimately incoherent piece of cinema.</fullReview>

		<username>Psi</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>An undeniably powerful but puzzling liberal lecture</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The writer of Traffic, Stephen Gaghan, digs even deeper into corruption with this much ballyhooed political thriller.Like Traffic, there are several plot threads that all eventually weave together into a whole. Whereas Traffic's central theme was the corruption that resulted from drug trafficking, Syriana's is the corruption that springs from large corporations and the battle for control of the world's oil supply. One subplot involves CIA operative Bob Barnes (George Clooney) and his efforts to discover the truth about the whole situation, which brings about rather gruesome results. Another subplot involves the merger of two oil companies, Connex and Killen. Then there's the prince (Alexander Siddig) who has plans to carry out liberal reforms that will help his country obtain full value for their oil. He forms a partnership with a troubled energy analyst played by Matt Damon. On top of all this, Syriana also takes time to focus on the trials and tribulations of a group of Pakistani teenagers, and some laid off Middle Eastern workers.I personally regard Syriana as a brave and complex motion picture, and for those reasons it stands out among 2005's motion pictures.As I hinted in my review of Munich, however, bravery and complexity are not enough when it comes to making a great movie. A film such as this one needs to focus more clearly on what it is dealing with. For a portion of its running time, Syriana is - quite literally - all over the place. (Traffic shared a similar flaw; Gaghan tried to fit so much into his screenplay for that film that the director, Steven Soderbergh, had to fight valiantly to keep it under control.) At times, Syriana plays like a more adult, less violent version of Three Kings (which, incidentally, is no bad thing, considering how highly I regard that film). There are many moments where it is really effective at being the Very Important Message Movie that it wants to be, with regards to not only oil and government, but also family values. Unfortunately Syriana treads a fine line between conveying a serious message and being liberal propaganda - I didn't believe that Gaghan was ambiguous enough in his treatment of the material.At least his cast don't put a foot wrong. Any cast which includes George Clooney, Matt Damon, Christopher Plummer and William Hurt is an impressive one by me. And there are many surprises here. No, I'm not talking about Clooney's weight gain and beard - he'd have been almost as effective had he been slightly less unkempt (although I'm not knocking his performance). Rather, Matt Damon, who eventually won me over as a family man despite his interminably young features. Amanda Peet and Jeffrey Wright (recently seen in Broken Flowers) do their reputations no harm either, and Alexander Siddig (impressive in the underrated Kingdom Of Heaven) continues to enhance his.It's very difficult for me to put a finger on Syriana. On one hand, it's intelligent, it asks questions and leaves plenty of food for thought - on the other hand, it's incoherent, at times blatantly one-sided and occasionally reliant on cheap tricks to keep the audience interested. It's like a lesser Munich, the difference being Spielberg has a better grasp of how to keep the audience involved. However, I admire Syriana's subject matter and general refusal to compromise, and for its artistic value alone, I recommend it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Important, Well Made, Confusing - But You Knew All That</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Syriana" is important, well made, and confusing. But, you probably know all that from reviews.Yes, it is all about America and the West selling our souls to service our addiction to petroleum in the Middle East. There are really rich, really powerful CIA agents, FBI agents, oil men, and lawyers cutting really dirty deals, sleeping with foul enemies, and sacrificing any integrity they or the US have ever had just to get to more money, more power, and more oil.It's about corrupt Middle Eastern leaders who live filthy rich lives and don't much care about where all that money comes from, or how long it is going to last, or what their people will do after the oil runs out, which it will do, as the movie points out, and soon.It's about the poor guest workers, many Muslims, the ones who don't have oil, who do much of the work in oil-rich Gulf nations, and who are treated like dirt by their richer Muslim brothers.It's about madrassas that teach pure Koran and serve as recruiting grounds for desperate young men who can be convinced to blow themselves up for a promise that their family will receive financial, and heavenly, rewards.The plot is not linear; it does not focus on a single character. There are sheiks in the desert hunting with falcons (cool gyrfalcon shot); there are poor Pakistanis struggling to survive in the Gulf; there are CIA agents, Hizbollah members and double agents on the prowl in Beirut; there is a housewife and mother and even some kids.It IS confusing. The movie does not make itself easy to understand. For example, in the scenes where Arabs and Pakistanis interact, IIRC, the movie doesn't communicate to the viewer: These are Pakistanis, from Pakistan, they are speaking Urdu; they are poor; their country has no oil; they've come here for work, and, on the other side, these are Arabs; they are local; they look down on the workers from Pakistan ... and the viewer would miss all of the culture clash and tension at the heart of those interactions.But it's a really well-made, truly movie film. There were scenes that broke my heart, that made me tense, and that reminded me of the high cost of petroleum.I do wish the movie had worked harder to make itself easier to understand. One of the great gifts of film is that complex and world-changing ideas can be communicated with images. It's evident that the filmmakers here wanted to get across an important message. Making their movie so hard to follow did not facilitate that task</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Work your way through this one...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Stephen Gaghan is a master psychologist in addition to being a uniquely creative writer and director. He knows how to take a controversial topic, spread it over a period of time and from vantages that involve everyone who would ever view his information, and pace a film in such away that his viewers must stay glued to the screen and soundtrack so that not a moment of the powerful bits of intrigue he is relating fall out of place. 		<shortDescription>Bewitching but bewildering</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A visually impressive film that bears many hallmarks of its one of its producers (Soderbergh) in its execution: hand-held cam sequences, bleached location footage. Like so many political thrillers, the plot gives the impression of moving very fast largely due to a cryptic, convoluted script. I rate both Matt Damon and George Clooney who fulfil expectation; Amanda Peet, Alexander Siddig and Jeffrey Wright are thoroughly convincing and a great sleaze double act in Christophers Cooper and Plummer provides some genuine 'bad guy' frisson in a film where it can be hard to tell who is. 6/10</fullReview>

		<date>2006-03-06</date>
		<username>Ben Rosamond</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>It's complicated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The phrase 'it's complicated' issues from George Clooney's character at least twice during this film. And 'it's complicated' would certainly work as an accurate tag line for this compelling, intricate movie. It's complicated - rather obviously - because of Syriana's multi-perspectives, interwoven and opaque plotting. It's also complicated in another way. Syriana has a rather obvious critical message at its core. But it is also a film about rationality, or more precisely 'rationalities' and how politics is organised around the intersection and conflict between different logics. On display we have the correspondence between the rationality of US national interests and that of corporate America. We have the largely unthinking (but gradually unravelling) rationality of the American intelligence services. There is the rationality of the law and the messy compromises it must make with the state in pursuit of 'justice' and there is the perverse rationality of the route from degraded oil worker to suicide bomber. In a sense Syriana is about the idea that politics is about making choices between these conflicting logics, and in so doing the film exposes for the nonsense it is the dominant simple story that the neoconservative Bush administration tells its citizens and the world at large about it supposed moral purpose. From this standpoint perhaps the most interesting story line within the film is that surrounding Matt Damon's energy market analyst. Within this character we find two compelling strands of liberalism. As a technocrat, his governing logic is pure economic liberalism. Witness the ruthlessly logical advice he gives to the prospective Emir by inscribing a few simple cartographic lines in the desert sand. At the same time, he is guided by a belief in political liberalism. As these two liberal thought lines converge, so their logic is compelling and yet - of course - they offend quite fundamentally the corporate and foreign policy interests of his home country. Damon's return at the end of the movie from symbolically neutral Geneva to the bosom of his American family is profoundly emblematic of the defeat of his liberalism and the restoration of the hegemonic status quo.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Chuck French</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Mainstream disguised as an independent film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Syriana seem to have all the makings of a great film. It starts out fine, lots of things going on all over the world, tangentially related to the oil business but with no immediate, linear connections. While you had to pay attention, it was not difficult to follow. This is not at all unusual in an independent film or in life. In fact it is what you have come to expect. Crash, Traffic,and Magnolia, to name three very fine films all start out the same way. You assume that the dots will get connected and everyone will have a significant part to play before it is over.We meet all the various people that are going to be involved over the first hour in their home environments and they gradually start crossing each other's paths in the ways you would expect. It is pretty clear that is not an oil-cowboy movie as we gradually find out that just about everyone has some dirty linen, skeletons in the closet, axes to grind, career compromises and so forth. It starts to get serious and people get closer and closer together, start impacting each other's lives in very dangerous and sometimes fatal ways. Yet we are not sure how this is going to play out, which is exactly what you have come to expect and want. But then things take a turn for the worse and we head towards melodrama with a tragic accident that does not seem to affect one of our main players to any great extent. It keeps going downhill, the various characters start playing very familiar roles as corporate and government semi-bad guys and so forth. You see the same scenes you have seen before in Tom Clancy type movies and other films of corporate corruption. We get the denouement which is unsurprising and the movie is over. All the various plot lines have been resolved, everything is wrapped up in a very neat and tidy fashion. There are no loose ends, nothing is left to chance. No one is left out there who might upset the apple cart, make a difference in the future. Though no one rides off into the sunset, it ends with essentially the same result. We end up with a very mainstream movie acting like an independent film. Too bad, it could have been a winner.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An interesting, topical movie that could have been great</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You certainly can't fault writer-director Stephen Gaghan for trying to make an important film about this nation's dependency on oil from the Middle East and the lengths to which our government and Big Oil will go to maintain ties, even with rather questionable governments that are far from democratic.(Wait, I thought we were about fostering democracy throughout the world. Isn't that why we invaded Iraq? Or, was it WMDs? Or, was it to oust a brutal dictator who was once our buddy? Or, was it so we'd be welcomed with rose petals as liberators?)The trouble with Gaghan's film is that he tries to tackle way too many stories in one film and winds up with a movie where none of the characters is given much depth.This film has one too many subplots (about a character's father) and one too many stories. There actually is another film in one of the stories dealing with immigrants working in the Middle East and how easily they can be manipulated by fanatics.Gaghan isn't a very good director, really, as his debut attempt proved. And, frankly, although he won an Oscar for his script for the over-rated "Traffic" (2000), there were more deserving writers that year - the Coen brothers for "O, Brother, Where Art Thou?" or Steve Kloves for "Wonder Boys." The performances in "Syriana" are pretty good, but the characters are so thinly written, that we never find out what makes them tick. And some of the characters are so incredibly mysterious, we remain confused. Gaghan also seems to cop out at the end, not really bothering to explain a crucial plot point involving what very well might be a patsy.Gaghan tries to keep all this stories together and then tie them up at the end, but the characters remain so aloof and impersonal and the story so cold, that we're never truly engaged in what's happening.This film would have worked much better, been more trenchant and could have made a potent political statement about the state of affairs right now had Gaghan concentrated on, say, two story lines and made the plotting tighter. Instead, he bites off much more than he can chew.</fullReview>
